questions.text: The following marked structure will develop into?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Median umbilical ligament

The structure marked ‘A’ in the given diagram of a developing embryo represents the allantois.
The median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the fetal urachus and the urachus is a fibrous remnant of the allantois. 

 

Option (B) Medial umbilical ligament is a remnant of obliterated fetal umbilical arteries

(Option C) The ligamentum teres hepatis (round ligament of the liver) represents the obliterated left umbilical vein. 

(Option D) The falciform ligament is a sickle-shaped, broad, and thin fold of peritoneum that attaches the liver to the front body wall and divides the liver into the left lobe and right lobe.

Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page. No- 182, 249.

questions.text:
Which aortic arch defect is responsible for the given defect?


 
1. 4th Left
2. 4th Right
3. 6th Right
4. 6th Left
questions.solution:
Answer: (4). 6th Left

The given image shows a patent ductus arteriosus. This is an acyanotic congenital heart defect, involving a patent left-to-right shunt between the pulmonary artery and the aorta, as shown in the figure below.

 

After birth, the ductus arteriosus undergoes active constriction and eventual obliteration. A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the DA fails to completely close postnatally. The DA is thought to be derived from the distal part of the embryonic left sixth aortic arch.

(Option A, B) Fourth aortic arch - The right arch contributes to the right proximal subclavian artery. The left arch gives rise to the medial portion of the aortic arch.

(Option C) Sixth aortic arch - The right and left arches separate into ventral and dorsal segments. The ventral segments are responsible for the formation of the pulmonary arteries bilaterally. The left ventral arch also contributes to the formation of the pulmonary trunk. The right dorsal arch regresses. The left dorsal arch forms the ductus arteriosus, which later closes and is termed the ligamentum arteriosum.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 940

choices.text: Ipsilateral fine motor activity of the fingers

questions.text: A patient presented with a stab wound to the neck. On workup, injury to the lateral part of the dorsal column was found. Which of the following is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1) Ipsilateral Proprioception in Upper Limb

The given vignette presents a stab wound with an injury to the dorsal column which carries fibers of conscious proprioception, along with sensations of vibration and fine touch.
  • The fibers in the dorsal column are organized somatotopically with the medial fibers carrying sensations from the lower limb through the fasciculus gracilis.
  • Fasciculus cuneatus carries fibers of the upper limb to its respective nucleus and is located laterally.



Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 165- 167.

questions.text: A medical student was yawning during his afternoon anatomy lecture. His jaw was arrested while yawning. Which muscle is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lateral Pterygoid.

Yawning involves a wide opening of the mouth. Opening of the mouth involves active depression (downward movement) and this movement is brought about mainly by the contraction of the lateral pterygoid.

  • In the wide opening of the mouth, this hinge-like movement is followed by gliding of the disc and the head of the mandible in the upper compartment.
  • At the end of this movement, the head comes to lie under the articular tubercle. Thus, in this medical student, the arrest of yawning occurs likely due to failure of the gliding forward of the articular disc by the lateral pterygoid.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 547.

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive pain and swelling anterior to the left ear lobule. Which anatomical structure is responsible for pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Investing Layer of Deep Cervical Fascia

The vignette mentions a patient presenting with a swelling anterior to the left ear lobule, which is painful/ tender. This is likely to indicate a swelling of the parotid gland. 
  • The investing layer of the deep cervical fascia forms a capsule for the gland. 
  • Parotid swellings are very painful due to the unyielding nature of the parotid fascia, and thus, the most appropriate answer to the question is the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia.
  • The capsule of the parotid gland formed by the fascia is innervated by the great auricular nerve and skin over the gland is supplied by the great auricular nerve (C2, C3). (Option C)

#Controversial: Due to the variability in the exact wording of the recall question and options, this question remains controversial. But, Option D is preferable over Option C, since parotid swellings are painful due to the firm nature of the fascia.
If the question had which structure was responsible for the transmission of pain - then option (C) would be better. 


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 477, 505.

questions.text:
A patient presented to the OPD with inflammation of the tonsils. The patient also had pain in the ipsilateral ear. Which nerve is responsible for the pain in the ear due to tonsillitis?

1. Auricular Branch of X nerve
2. Tympanic Branch of IX nerve
3. VII Nerve
4. V Nerve
questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Tympanic Branch of IX nerve

Due to the shared innervation by the glossopharyngeal nerve, the pain of tonsillitis can be referred to the glossopharyngeal nerve which gives sensory supply to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane, the middle ear, the auditory tube, the mastoid antrum, and air cells. 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No 149.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with loss of sensation over the lateral three and a half digits on the volar side. He also had associated pain. The patient would sometimes wake up from sleep due to pain and hanging the hand over the edge of the bed would help relieve the pain. What is the most probable site of injury and which test can be performed to confirm the same?
questions.solution:
Answer is option (1) Carpal Tunnel and Durkan Compression Test

This patient reports loss of sensation/ paresthesia over the lateral three and a half digits on the volar side. This corresponds to the sensory distribution of the median nerve.
  • The median nerve may be compressed at the level of the carpal tunnel. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome arises due to anatomic compression or inflammation. 
  • Clinical examination of the Median Nerve involves:
  1. Assessment of sensory loss: The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve passes above the carpal tunnel and supplies the skin of the thenar eminence. Thus, this area is typically spared, and sensory loss over the thenar eminence would indicate a more proximal lesion.
  2. Assessment of motor function: The median nerve supplies five muscles including three muscles of the thenar eminence - flexor pollicis brevis (FPB), opponens pollicis (OP) and abductor pollicis brevis (APB), along with the first and second lumbricals.  In severe or advanced CTS, muscles of the thenar eminence may be affected leading to weakness of thumb abduction (APB)  and thumb opposition (OP.) 
  3. Provocative maneuvers/ tests:
  • Phalen test:  The patient brings the dorsal surfaces of the hands against each other to provide hyperflexion of the wrist. If pain/ paresthesia in the distribution of the median nerve is elicited the test is positive.
 
 
  • Tinel test: Percussion performed over the course of the median nerve just proximal to the carpal tunnel elicits pain/ paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve.
 
 
  • Durkan test or manual carpal compression: Pressure is applied over the transverse carpal ligament for 30 seconds. Pain/ paresthesia indicates a positive result.
 
 
  • Hand elevation test: The patient raises the hands above the head for one minute. If the symptoms are reproduced, the test is positive.
Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 297, 298, 303.

choices.text: Left colic vein and middle colic vein

questions.text: In a patient with liver cirrhosis, anastomosis between which of the following will be seen?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Left gastric vein and esophageal vein

A patient suffering from liver cirrhosis is likely to have portal hypertension.
  • Patients with obstructed portal blood flow, are likely to have significant collateral circulation which occurs through sites of portocaval anastomoses/ communications - one of them being left gastric and esophageal veins.
  • In patients with portal hypertension, there is increased blood flow through these channels, leading to dilation. They may present with complications such as variceal bleeding, or hemorrhoids, and are thus clinically significant.
The following are sites of portocaval anastomosis:




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1167.

questions.text:
The marked structure ‘X’ represents a defect in which of the following?

1. Internal Oblique
2. Fascia Transversalis
3. Transversus Abdominis
4. External Oblique
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fascia Transversalis


The structure marked by ‘X’ represents the deep inguinal ring. The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the Fascia Transversalis. 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, approximately midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis, and about 1 cm above the inguinal ligament. It is oval, with a roughly vertical long axis. Its size varies between individuals but it is usually 1–2 cm wide in adults and larger in the male. It is related above to the arched lower margin of transversus abdominis and medially to the interfoveolar ligament.

*  Relation of Deep Inguinal Ring: 



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1080.

questions.text: Weakness of which of the following can cause a hernia superior to the pubic tubercle and medial to the inferior epigastric artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Conjoint Tendon

The vignette describes a hernia present superior to the pubic tubercle. (Inguinal hernia)

  • The weakness of the conjoint tendon, which forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and guards the superficial inguinal ring, will predispose to direct inguinal hernias.
  • The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibres of internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line. It descends behind the superficial inguinal ring and acts to strengthen the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. Medially, the upper fibres of the tendon fuse with the anterior wall of the rectus sheath, and laterally, some fibres may blend with the interfoveolar ligament.
     




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1078.

questions.text:
Following are the landmarks around the knee joint. Injury to which area will cause failure of ankle dorsiflexion?

 
1. B 
2. C 
3. A 
4. D
questions.solution:
Answer (2) C

The given image shows a radiographic film of the knee in the AP view.
  • The key landmarks identified are the lower end of the femur, below which the area of increased opacity represents:
  1. Patella (marked A)
  2. The head of the fibula (marked B)
  3. The neck of the fibula (marked C)
  4. Upper end of the tibia. (marked D)
  • Muscles of the leg consist of an anterior group of extensor muscles, which produce dorsiflexion (extension) of the ankle which receives innervation from the tibial nerve which runs posteriorly across the popliteal fossa, and down the back of the leg. It continues laterally around the neck of the fibula to supply motor and sensory innervation to the leg. Hence injury to the neck of the fibula (option C) would result in failure of dorsiflexion of ankle. 
  • Posterior group of flexor muscles, which produce plantar flexion  & Lateral group of muscles, which evert the ankle both of which are supplied by the superficial and deep peroneal nerves respectively, which are branches of the common peroneal nerve.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1415.

questions.text:
Identify the structure shown:

1. Glomerulus
2. Hassal’s corpuscles
3. Islets of Langerhans
4. Leydig cells
questions.solution:
The above histology image shows the glomerulus. (option 1)

  • The glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium.
  • Blood enters the tuft through an afferent arteriole and leaves it through an efferent arteriole.
  • It is supported by the mesangium containing mesangial cells and a non-cellular mesangial matrix.
Option 4 The Connective tissue between the seminiferous tubules are made up of Leydig cells, Collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, etc.


Fig: Leydig Cells

Fig: Islets of langerhans

Fig: Hassel's Corpuscles


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 898.

questions.text:
Regarding the cardiac action potential, which of the following is correct?

1. The slope of Phase 1 is due to the opening of Na+ channels.
2. The slope of Phase 2 is due to the opening of Ca+2 channels.
3. The slope of Phase 3 is due to the closure  of Na+ channels and opening of K+ channels.
4. The slope of Phase 4 is due to the overactivity of Na+/K+ pump.
questions.solution:
Answer: (2)  The slope of Phase 2 is due to the opening of Ca+2 channels.

  • The transmembrane action potential of single cardiac muscle cells is characterized by rapid depolarization (phase 0), an initial rapid repolarization (phase 1), a plateau (phase 2), and a slow repolarization process (phase 3) that allows return to the resting membrane potential (phase 4).
  • The initial depolarization is due to Na+ influx through rapidly opening Na+ channels (the Na+ current, INa).
  • The inactivation of Na+ channels contributes to the rapid repolarization phase. Ca2+ influx through more slowly opening Ca2+ channels (the Ca2+ current, I Ca) produces the plateau phase, and repolarization is due to net K+ efflux through multiple types of K+ channels.
  • Recorded extracellularly, the summed electrical activity of all the cardiac muscle fibers is the ECG.




Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 520.

questions.text:
In the adjoining spirogram, which of the following is indicated by the blue arrow?

1. FRC
2. ERV
3. RV
4. FVC
questions.solution:
Answer: (1) FRC

Blue Arrow represents the amount of air left in the lung at the end of normal expiration. This includes ERV(Expiratory reserve volume) and residual volume(RV) - together referred to as FRC (functional residual capacity).

 
  • VC = IRV + VT + ERV
  • VC = IC + ERV
  • TLC = VC + RV
  • TLC = IC + FRC
  • FRC = ERV + RV 

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 629.

questions.text:
Points A to E are given in the adjoining graph of the action potential. Which of the following is correct?

1. Point A to point C is due to opening of slow Na+ channels
2, Point B to point D is due to opening of fast K+ channels
3. Nerve is hyperexcitable at point E
4. Point A to point D is the refractory period
questions.solution:
Answer(4) Point A to point D is the refractory period.

In the given figure which represents the changes in membrane potential during initiation of an action potential, various events have been marked.
  1. The resting membrane potential of neurons is usually about –70 mV.
  2. In response to a depolarizing stimulus, some of the voltage-gated Na+ channels open and Na+ enters the cell and the membrane is brought to its threshold potential. (point A)
  3. Due to a positive feedback loop, there is a rapid upstroke (point B) till membrane potential reaches maximum/ overshoot. (point C)
  4. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels contributes to repolarization (point D).
  5. The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state (they stay open resulting in K+ ion loss and further negative charge) explains the after-hyperpolarization (point E), followed by a return to the resting membrane potential. The phase of after-hyperpolarization is also refractory to further stimuli.
* Point A-D is a part of refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not ellicit an action potential.
 



The refractory period is divided into an Absolute and a relative Refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 91.

questions.text: In the absence of surfactant, which of the following is seen?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Surface tension increases, compliance decreases

Surfactant decreases the surface tension of the fluid interface.
  • An important factor affecting the compliance of the lungs is the surface tension of the film of fluid that lines the alveoli. 
  • A deficiency of surfactant would lead to increased surface tension (due to the absence of the tension-lowering effect of the surfactant), which would lead to decreased compliance.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 631.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of trauma. The patient has hemoglobinuria and undergoes a series of laboratory investigations. His potassium is 5.5mmol/L. What is the effect on peripheral neurons?
questions.solution:
Answer(4). RMP becomes more positive

The patient has presented with a history of trauma with hemoglobinuria. This indicates that there is injury to the body tissues at the cellular level leading to leakage of K+ into the blood, leading to hyperkalemia.  
  • The contribution of the K+ channel to the RMP is maximal due to a high coefficient of permeability.
  • Thus, the resting membrane potential is close to the equilibrium potential for K+.
  • It follows that changes in the external concentration of this ion can have major effects on the resting membrane potential.
  • If the extracellular level of K+ is increased (hyperkalemia), the resting potential moves closer to the threshold for eliciting an action potential and the neuron becomes more excitable. (More positive)
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 91, 92.

questions.text:
With reference to the adjacent diagram, which of the following is correct?

1. A- Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin, D- PAHA
2. A- Bicarbonate, B- Glucose, C- Inulin, D- PAHA
3. A- Inulin, B- Bicarbonate, C- Glucose, D- PAHA
4. A- Glucose, B- Inulin, C- PAHA, D- Bicarbonate
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin, D- PAHA

The given graph of the percent filtered load remaining along the distance of the nephron represents the relative amounts of various substances which are filtered through the glomerulus into the tubules.

  • Substance A is being completely reabsorbed within the proximal convoluted tubule and thus likely represents glucose or amino acids. 
  • Substance B is absorbed to a great extent in the PCT, but is still excreted in the urine in minor quantities. This is likely to represent the curve of electrolytes such as Na+, HCO3-, or even water.
  • Substance C's filtered load (i.e. amount) stays constant throughout the nephron and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted, representing Inulin, which is ideal for the estimation of the glomerular filtration rate.
  • Substance D is not only freely filtered but also secreted to the extent that it is removed completely by the body. This is likely to be para-amino hippuric acid (PAH), a substance that is used for the estimation of renal plasma flow.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 677, 681.

questions.text:
Which mode of transport is depicted in the image given below?

1. Secondary active transport
2. Endocytosis
3. Facilitated diffusion
4. Primary active transport
questions.solution:
The given image shows the transport of molecules across the plasma membrane which is represented by the phospholipid bilayer.

  • Substances (green) are diffusing from outside the cell membrane to inside. The transport involves the presence of a carrier protein.
  • The molecules bind to the protein causing a conformational change following which the molecule goes inside the cell.
  • This is likely to represent facilitated diffusion.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 48.

questions.text: In hot summers, a farmer while working in the field collapsed. Vitals are noted as: Temperature: 104°F; Pulse Rate – 110 BPM. Which of the following is least likely to occur in this case?
questions.solution:
Given the history, this is most likely a case of heat stroke. Patients with heat stroke don't sweat leading to high temperatures.

  • Heat stroke is considered a medical emergency and leads to many indices of homeostatic imbalance: tachycardia, rapid shallow breathing, dizziness, anhidrosis i.e. a lack of sweating, dry and hot skin, muscle cramping, confusion, and seizures.
  • The clinical manifestations of heatstroke reflect a total loss of thermoregulatory function.
  • Typical vital-sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, the historical and physical triad of exposure to a heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and a core temperature >40.5°C helps establish the preliminary diagnosis

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3637.

questions.text: An old patient presented with resting tremor, rigidity and emotional blunting. Which of the following represents the likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Answer(1). Basal ganglia

This patient has rigidity, a resting hand tremor, and emotional blunting.
  • These symptoms are most likely due to Parkinson's disease, which is caused by degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. (part of basal ganglia)
  • This loss of dopaminergic neurons leads to a progressive deficiency of dopamine available to inhibit the thalamus.
  • This results in decreased stimulation of the motor cortex by the thalamus, leading to the classic symptoms of bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3387.

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions and was diagnosed as a case of RDS. What is most likely deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Lecithin

Deficiency of mature surfactant leads to RDS.

  • Lecithin (DPPC) constitutes 90% of surfactant composition.
  • Surfactant deficiency (decreased production and secretion) is the primary cause of RDS.
  • The failure to attain an adequate FRC and the tendency of affected lungs to become atelectatic correlate with high surface tension and the absence of pulmonary surfactant.
  • The major constituents of surfactant are dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (lecithin), phosphatidylglycerol, apoproteins (surfactant proteins SP-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D), and cholesterol.
  • Surfactant is present in high concentrations in fetal lung homogenates by 20 wk of gestation, but it does not reach the surface of the lungs until later. It appears in amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 wk of gestation. Mature levels of pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 wk of gestation.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 850.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors are Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase dependent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) II, VII, IX, X

Prothrombin (factor II) and several other proteins of the blood clotting system (Factors VII, IX, and X) and proteins C and S, are dependent on Vitamin K which helps in their carboxylation for conversion to their active form. The above process is an example of posttranslational modification of clotting factors. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 555.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of lethargy and weakness in between meals. The symptoms disappeared on feeding. No glycogen was present in the liver. Which of these enzymes could be deficient in the child?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of lethargy and weakness that disappear on feeding are suggestive of hypoglycemia. The vignette further mentions liver examination findings revealing No glycogen suggesting a deficiency in glycogen synthesis.

Glycogen synthase is the enzyme responsible for catalyzing the transfer of glucose from UDP-glucose to the nonreducing ends of glycogen chains, leading to the synthesis of glycogen.

 

Deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to synthesize glycogen (rate-limiting step of glycogenesis), which results in hypoglycemia between meals. The symptoms disappear in the fed state because glucose obtained from the meal maintains blood glucose levels.

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 178.

questions.text: An adolescent boy has muscle cramps and low lactate after exercise. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has McArdle disease (glycogen storage disease type V). 
  • This condition is caused by a deficiency of myophosphorylase, an isoenzyme of glycogen phosphorylase present in muscle tissue.
  • Deficiency leads to decreased breakdown of glycogen during exercise, resulting in poor exercise tolerance, muscle cramps, and rhabdomyolysis (eg, red urine), as occurred in this patient.
  • Approximately 50% of patients report burgundy-colored urine after exercise, which is the consequence of exercise-induced myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis. Intense myoglobinuria after vigorous exercise may cause acute renal failure. In rare cases, electromyographic findings may suggest an inflammatory myopathy and the diagnosis can be confused with polymyositis.
     

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 724.

questions.text: A child presents with blindness and hypotonia. On examination, there is no hepatomegaly. Fundoscopy revealed a cherry red spot. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with a cherry red spot on examination with concomitant neurological abnormalities such as blindness and hypotonia raises suspicion for a lysosomal storage disorders.

  • The cherry red spot observed on fundoscopy is a hallmark of gangliosidosis due to the accumulation of ganglioside (GM2 in Tay Sachs) in the ganglion cells of the retina.
  • It is not seen in Gaucher disease or Hurler syndrome, while Niemann Pick disease is a close differential.
  • However, Niemann Pick disease has prominent hepatosplenomegaly, which is classically absent in Tay Sachs disease, thus clinching our diagnosis.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 708, 3054.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presents with acute gouty arthritis. Which of these would be found in the blood?
questions.solution:
High urate and lactate are to be found in the blood of the given paitent.

The patient presents with an acute flare of gout, in the setting of chronic alcoholism, as indicated by the vignette.

Central to ethanol metabolism and its pathologies is the increased [NADH]/ [NAD+] redox potential (Hence, option 1 is incorrect), which is due to the oxidation of ethanol by alcohol dehydrogenase leading to excess production of NADH.

 

Ethanol metabolism causes increased NADH/NAD+ ratio in the liver, causing:
1. Lactic acidosis due to increased pyruvate conversion to lactate.
2. Fasting hypoglycemia due to decreased gluconeogenesis due to more conversion of OAA to malate
3. Ketoacidosis due to the diversion of acetyl-CoA into ketogenesis rather than the TCA cycle
4. Lactate is known to increase renal urate reabsorption thereby decreasing its excretion by the kidneys and causing hyperuricemia. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 214,411.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct with regard to the response of adipose tissue to the low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
A low insulin/ glucagon ratio represents a person in the fasting state, and will result in metabolic modifications to provide energy to the tissues of the body. This is also seen in states of stress.

  • Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in the adipose tissue is activated during the fasting state.
  • HSL cleaves triacylglycerols (TAGs) into free fatty acids (FFAs) and glycerol. These FFAs can then be used as an energy source by other tissues in the body.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 338, 358.

questions.text: What is the cause of black urine in infancy?
questions.solution:
Dark staining of diapers or black urine in infants can be a characteristic symptom of an autosomal recessive amino acid metabolism defect, Alkaptonuria.

  • It is caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • This acid is oxidized to benzoquinone acetic acid and excreted in the urine, which on exposure to air turns black.
The condition has three characteristic symptoms:
  1. Homogentisic aciduria (the urine contains elevated levels of HA, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing,)
  2. Early onset of arthritis in the large joints
  3. Deposition of black pigment (ochronosis) in cartilage and collagenous tissue

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 304.

questions.text: A child presents with bleeding gums and decreased wound healing. What is the reason for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has easy bleeding/bruising and gingivitis (Swollen and bleeding gums), findings indicative of vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy).

  • Vitamin C (Ascorbic Acid) is a required cofactor for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases, respectively, during collagen synthesis.
  • Impaired hydroxylation in vitamin C deficiency compromises collagen's tensile strength, increasing capillary wall fragility and causing petechiae/ecchymoses, mucosal bleeding (eg, nosebleeds), and perifollicular hemorrhages.  Periodontal disease (gingival erythema/edema/bleeding) and hyperkeratotic follicles (due to keratin plugging) with coiled/corkscrew hairs are also common features. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 540

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral muscle weakness and walking on toes. On examination, there is pitting edema, dilated cardiac shadow and fine crepts on auscultation. Patient and his family consume rice as the staple food. Which of the following should be used in evaluation ?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with symptoms of wet beriberi, which is caused by thiamine deficiency.

  • Moreover, the consumption of rice as a staple food could be a contributing factor, as polished rice lacks thiamine.
  • Thiamine is an important coenzyme for various enzymes, including transketolase.
  • RBC transketolase activity can be measured as an indicator of thiamine status.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 528.

questions.text: A patient has diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia. This indicates a deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Pellagra is due to niacin deficiency and is characterized by 3 Ds: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia (the 4th D being death):

  • Dermatitis is bilateral and symmetric on sun-exposed areas of the body and is characterized by rough, thick, scaly skin.
  • Diarrhea is due to atrophy (and occasional ulceration) of the columnar epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Dementia is due to neuronal degeneration in the brain and spinal cord, with lesions like those associated with pernicious anemia.


Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 534,538.

questions.text:
A patient presented with alopecia, skin rash and ulcer. He has a diet mainly consisting of raw egg white. Which nutrient deficiency is associated with this condition?

1. Niacin
2. Thiamine
3. Pyridoxine
4. Biotin
questions.solution:
Biotin deficiency is rare but can occur secondary to poor diet, excessive raw egg white consumption (due to high levels of biotin-binding avidin in egg whites), and congenital disorders of biotin metabolism.

  • Patients with biotin deficiency present with nonspecific symptoms, including changes in mental status, myalgias, anorexia, and chronic dermatologic changes such as macular dermatitis.
  • Biotin-deficient individuals can also develop metabolic acidosis as a result of increased conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid.
  • Apart from such individuals or those maintained on total parenteral nutrition for many months, biotin deficiency is virtually unknown.

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 538.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with cough. Lab investigations reveal hypercalcemia. Histopathology reveals large atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a chronic smoker presenting with cough and hypercalcemia. Lung carcinoma is being suspected and lung biopsy has been taken to identify the histological subset of lung cancer. 

  • While Cushing syndrome and SIADH are commonly associated with small cell carcinoma, hypercalcemia due to PTHrP is characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Adenocarcinoma may have hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (clubbing) while large cell carcinoma may produce hCG leading to gynaecomastia.
  • Thus, a smoker presenting with cough, hypercalcemia and large atypical cells on biopsy is most likely to have squamous cell carcinoma.

Fig: Keratin Pearls seen in Squamous Type of Lung Malignancy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 718,719.

questions.text: 8-year-old child presented with cola-coloured urine for 4 days and facial puffiness for 2 days. Creatinine was initially 1.3. She had a history of pyoderma 2 weeks back. What is the electron microscopic finding in this case?
questions.solution:
This describes a child with a history of recent pyoderma infection which may be caused by Streptococcus.
  • Cola-colored urine or smoky brown urine indicates gross hematuria likely indicating the child has acute glomerulonephritis (GN).
  • A provisional diagnosis of post-streptococcal GN can be made, which is the most common cause of acute GN in India.
  • Subepithelial deposits (humps) are seen on EM in PSGN.
 
LM: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG C3 along the glomerular basement Membrane and mesangium.
EM: primarily subepithelial humps are seen. subendothelial deposits can seen in early disease stages.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 908.

questions.text: A patient presents with retroperitoneal bleed with a history of pain and swelling in both knees. Which factors deficiency can lead to the given picture?
questions.solution:
Answer: (2) Factors 8, 9

The patient presents with a history of bleeding and we suspect a bleeding disorder. 


 
  • The clinical presentation of a retroperitoneal bleed with pain suggests a deep tissue bleed.
  • The pain and swelling in both knees (hemarthrosis), is also a deep tissue bleed. Thus, we suspect clot-factor deficiency/ disorders. 
  • The most likely factor deficiencies leading to such a presentation are factors 8 and 9, which are both involved in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.
Recall bias: Some examinees also mentioned other demographic history details of the patient being mentioned in the question - such as the age of the patient (young/ 10-20 years), and sex of the patient (male) - which further supports the diagnosis of hemophilia A and B due to its X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 669.

questions.text:
A child has a mass in the jaw. The child is noted to have t(8;14), and a biopsy of the lesion is shown below. Identify the disease in this child?

1. Burkitt Lymphoma
2. AML
3. B-ALL
4. Follicular Lymphoma
questions.solution:
Answer:(1) Burkitt Lymphoma

The findings of a jaw mass with translocation (8:14) and biopsy revealing monomorphic, medium-sized cells with round nuclei, multiple dark nucleoli, basophilic cytoplasm and prominent cytoplasmic lipid vacuoles towards one pole of the cell are highly suggestive of Burkitt Lymphoma.

The Most probable diagnosis Based on Histopathology " Starry Sky" pattern is Burkitt Lymphoma.
The tumor cells express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10 and BCL6 a phenotype consistent with a germinal center B-cell origin.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 602.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for a BIRADS-V lesion?
questions.solution:
ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer.
  • High Ki-67 indicates a poor prognosis. 
  • p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, which on mutation acts as an oncogene. p53 positivity is associated with highly malignant breast cancers and has poor survival. 
  • The mutations in BRCA1 gene account for up to 40% of familial breast cancers. These tumors are high-grade, hormone receptor-negative, and aneuploid and do not have a good prognosis.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 822.

questions.text:
A 10-year old child presents with anemia and jaundice and Splenomegaly. Platelet count is 2.5 lakh and TLC is 7500. There is a history of similar complaints in the elder brother. Peripheral smear findings are as shown. What is the probable diagnosis and investigation required to confirm it?

1. Hereditary spherocytosis, Osmotic fragility test
2. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, Coombs test
3. PNH, Flow cytometry
4. HUS, Stool culture
questions.solution:
A child presenting with anemia and jaundice indicates that the etiology of the anemia is likely due to hemolytic jaundice.

The peripheral smear findings in the given case show spherocytes, which are small, dense, and lack central pallor; they can be seen in hereditary spherocytosis, hemolytic anemias of other causes such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AHA), and clostridial sepsis.
  • Only confusion here is between HS & AIHA.
  • HS will have family history, splenomegaly & early presentation.
  • AIHA does not present with a family history.
  • HS is caused by diverse mutations that lead to an insufficiency of membrane skeletal components. As a result of these alterations, the life span of affected red cells is decreased on average to 10 to 20 days from the normal 120 days. The pathogenic mutations most commonly affect ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2, the proteins involved in one of the two tethering interactions.
  • Laboratory Investigations that are done to confirm the diagnosis:
  • Osmotic Fragility test
  • Acid glycerol Lysis test
  • Eosin-5'-maleimide(EMA)- Binding test.
  • SDS- gel electrophoresis test



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 639.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is Hepatitis B positive. On kidney biopsy, a characteristic spike and dome pattern is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient who has chronic Hepatitis B is at risk of developing membranous nephropathy.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed on HPE which reveals the characteristic spike and dome pattern of the disease.
  • In most cases of secondary membranous nephropathy, these autoantibodies are absent, with rare reports of autoantibodies to PLA2R in membranous glomerulopathy associated with hepatitis B, cancer, and sarcoidosis.
  • Circulating deposits and glomerular deposits of these autoantibodies have correlated with the likelihood of a spontaneous remission, severity of IMN, and the response to therapy. Eighty percent of patients with MGN present with nephrotic syndrome and nonselective proteinuria.




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: Which of the following is the true statement regarding Mendelian disorders?
questions.solution:
• About 65% (2/3rd) of human monogenic disorders are autosomal dominant.
  •  25% (1/4th) are autosomal recessive (option A).
  • 5% (1/20th) are X-linked (option C).
  • The Y chromosome has a relatively small number of genes, and thus the frequency is much lower than 10% (1/10th)


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3652.

questions.text:
A 64-year old male went for a routine medical and was accidently found to have WBC counts - 95000/ mm3. The peripheral smear is examined. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
1. Bone Marrow Biopsy
2. Flow cytometry
3. BCR-ABL analysis
4. Chemotherapy
questions.solution:
• The elderly patient with raised WBC counts showing marked lymphocytosis (damaged lymphocytes -"smudge cells") are present. This is characterstic of CLL.
  • Immunophenotyping using flow cytometry is the investigation done to arrive at the diagnosis. CD-19+, CD20+, CD23+, CD5+.
  • Expectant Management  is treatment of choice for asymptomatic patient of CLL. The gold standard combination of CLL is Fludarabine, cyclophosphamide and Rituximab.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 598.

questions.text:
A 5-year old child has fever, dyspnea and cough. He started having chest pain. Further evaluation revealed left ventricular dysfunction. Biopsy findings are as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?

1. Acute rheumatic fever
2. Lymphocytic myocarditis
3. Chagas disease
4. Eosinophilic myocarditis
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette has a 5-year-old child presenting with fever and chest pain associated with dyspnea/cough and the echocardiogram reveals left ventricular dysfunction.
  • This clinical scenario is suggestive of myocarditis(likely viral).
  • The given image shows massive infiltration with mononuclear cells and occasional eosinophils associated with clear myocyte damage. This is diagnostic of lymphocytic myocarditis.(seen in viral myocarditis)
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 576.

questions.text: A child was found to have a rectal polyp. On histopathological examination, colonic epithelium and dilated glands with mucin is seen. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
The presence of a rectal polyp in a child is likely to be a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

  • Hamartomas are benign growths that are composed of a disorganized mixture of different types of tissues.
  • The histopathology findings of dilated glands with mucin, rather than an increased number of epithelial cells further corroborate the diagnosis of hamartoma. 
  • Most juvenile polyps are less than 3 cm in diameter. They are typically pedunculated, smooth-surfaced, reddish lesions with characteristic cystic spaces. Microscopic examination shows these cysts to be dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. The remainder of the polyp is composed of lamina propria expanded by mixed inflammatory infiltrates. The muscularis mucosae may be normal or attenuated.
     


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 810.

questions.text: A patient had fever and hepatomegaly. Owl eye inclusion bodies are seen in histopathology. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• CMV-infected cells exhibit gigantism of both the entire cell and its nucleus, which typically contains a large inclusion surrounded by a clear halo (“owl’s eye”).
  • Infected cells are strikingly enlarged, often to a diameter of 40 µm, and show cellular and nuclear pleomorphism.
  • Prominent intranuclear basophilic inclusions spanning one-half of the nuclear diameter are usually set off from the nuclear membrane by a clear halo.
  • Within the cytoplasm of infected cells, smaller basophilic inclusions can also be seen.
  • Diagnosis of CMV infection is made by demonstration of characteristic morphologic alterations in tissue sections, viral culture, rising antiviral antibody titer, and PCR-based detection of CMV DNA. Quantitative PCR based assays have revolutionized the approach to monitoring CMV infection in people after transplantation.
     


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 356.

choices.text: Hemolytic transfusion reaction due to ABO incompatibility

questions.text: A patient presented with severe pallor and weakness. Hb was found to be 4.6. The patient was transfused 4 units of blood over 6 hours. The patient developed breathlessness and crepitus. There was bilateral prominence of fissures on CXR. JVP was elevated. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
• The transfusion of multiple units of blood in this patient over a short span is likely to cause fluid overload leading to the signs & symptoms described. This is termed as TACO(transfusion-associated circulatory overload). 
  • TACO results in dyspnea, hypoxia, bilateral and predominantly alveolar infiltrates on chest Xray, frequent systolic hypertension, elevated brain natriuretic peptide.
  • Treatment requires stopping the transfusion and administrating oxygen and diuretics.




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 895.

questions.text: A Chronic Smoker who worked in a cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. Among the following options, exposure to which of the following can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
• Mesothelioma is most specific association of asbestosis.
  • Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis, which is distinguished from diffuse interstitial fibrosis resulting from other causes only by the presence of asbestos bodies. Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center that consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material.
  • Chest x-ray studies reveal irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. With advancement of the pneumoconiosis, a honeycomb pattern develops.
  • The disease may remain static or progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and death. Pleural plaques are usually asymptomatic and are detected on radiographs as circumscribed densities.
  • Asbestosis complicated by lung or pleural cancer is associated with a particularly grim prognosis.
  • Asbestos bodies are found in increased numbers in the lungs of patients with mesothelioma. Another marker of asbestos exposure, the asbestos plaque, has been previously discussed
     

Fig: High-power detail of an asbestos body, revealing the typical beading and knobbed ends


Fig: Asbestos Related Pleural plaques.

* Extra Edge :


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 726.

questions.text:
A biopsy of the bone marrow of a patient with leukocytosis is shown. The bleeding parameters include increased PT and aPTT. The disease is most commonly due to which mutation?

1. t(15;17)
2. t(8;21)
3. t(9;22)
4. ETV6 mutation
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows numerous Auer rods (marked with arrows) in the cytoplasm of cells in this bone marrow biopsy.

  • These cells likely represent promyelocytes, which are characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). They are particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) (acute promyelocytic leukemia - FAB M3 subtype)
  • The bleeding parameters reveal raised PT and aPTT both indicating that both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are activated, likely leading to a generalized deficiency of coagulation factors - this represents DIC.
  • Auer Rods are mostly seen in APML, which is a subtype of AML, asso. with t(15:17), which results in the formation of fusion gene called PML-RARA. Treatment includes administration of all-trans retinoic acid. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 619.

questions.text:
Identify the enzyme deficient in the below condition:

1. Hexosaminidase
2. Glucocerebrosidase
3. Sphingomyelinase
4. Alpha-1,4-glucosidase
questions.solution:
• In image atypical Gaucher cell with vacuolations and typical Gaucher cell with a “wrinkled tissue pattern” or “crumpled tissue paper appearance” are identified on bone marrow aspirate smear.
  • Gaucher disease is due to deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase). 
  • There are three clinical subtypes- type I, type II and type III.
  • Clinical Features include anemia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly and neurological features depending on the subtypes. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 251.

questions.text: In a patient planned for a cardiac surgical procedure. Which of the following is preferred antibiotic for prophylaxis:
questions.solution:
• The most common pathogens infecting incision sites after clean surgery are Staphylococci, specifically S. aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci.
  • Cephalosporins (first and second generation) are the best-studied antimicrobial agents for Surgical site infections (SSI) prevention in cardiac procedures, out of which cefazolin is the most extensively studied, and has shown better results than cefuroxime, which theoretically has broader gram-negative coverage, but increased resistance. 
  • The timing of antibiotic administration is crucial, with the first dose typically given within 60 minutes before the incision.
  • It is the preferred antibiotic for prophylaxis in such a case.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 209.

questions.text: A 50-year old chronic smoker with a 20-pack year history of smoking was on treatment for smoking cessation.  The patient was also on clonidine for withdrawal symptoms. He developed a pounding headache, three days after he stopped clonidine. What could be the likely cause for his headache?
questions.solution:
Rebound Hypertension could be the likely cause of the patient's headache.

  • When clonidine is abruptly stopped, the body may experience a rebound effect, where there is an increase in sympathetic nervous system activity and an increase in blood pressure.
  • Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist and a centrally acting antihypertensive agent.
  • Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting occur in some patients when doses of clonidine are missed for 1–2 days.
  • The syndrome is very similar to that seen in pheochromocytoma: plasma catecholamine (CA) concentration is increased.

    This is due to:
    (a)  Sudden removal of central sympathetic inhibition resulting in release of large quantities of stored CAs.
    (b) Super-sensitivity of peripheral adrenergic structures to CAs that develops due to chronic reduction of sympathetic tone during clonidine therapy.
    * A combination of α blocker with a β blocker, or a potent vasodilator (nitroprusside) or clonidine itself can be used to treat the syndrome.

    Severe hypertension, restlessness and sympathetic overactivity may occur shortly after discontinuing clonidine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 611.

questions.text: A patient on chemotherapy presented with thrombocytopenia. Which of the following drugs will be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
IL-3, IL-6, and IL-11 stimulate platelet production.

  • Oprelvekin (recombinant IL-11) was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for use in chemotherapy-associated thrombocytopenia.
  • Darbepoetin alfa and Epoetin alfa are recombinant human erythropoietin.
  • Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that is used for the treatment of severe neutropenia after high-dose cancer chemotherapy
  • Sargramostim is a recombinant Granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) used to treat neutropenia induced by chemotherapy.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page. No- 906.

questions.text: A farmer developed organophosphate poisoning. Atropine and pralidoxime were given. After 2 hours, a rise in temperature was noted. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Atropine administration is likely responsible for the rise in temperature.
 
  • This is due to the decrease in sweating since the body’s sweat glands are innervated by post-sympathetic cholinergic fibers.
  • Belladonna poisoning may occur due to drug overdose or consumption of seeds and berries of belladonna/datura plant. Children are highly susceptible. Manifestations are due to exaggerated pharmacological actions. 
  • Dry mouth, difficulty in swallowing and talking. Dry, flushed and hot skin (especially over face and neck), fever, difficulty in micturition, decreased bowel sounds.
  • A scarlet rash may appear. 
  • Dilated pupil, photophobia, blurring of near vision, palpitation. Excitement, psychotic behaviour, ataxia, delirium, dreadful visual hallucinations. 
  • Hypotension, weak and rapid pulse, cardiovascular collapse with respiratory depression. Convulsions and coma occur only in severe poisoning.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 132.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient was being managed on inhaler therapy. The patient complained of whitish oral thrush on buccal mucosa and tongue. Which is the drug used for this condition?
questions.solution:
Inhaled corticosteroids which are used for maintenance therapy result in the deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which can cause oropharyngeal candidiasis.
For oral candidiasis, 10 mg troche(lozenge) of clotrimazole is allowed to be dissolved in the mouth 3-4 times a day. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 842, 843.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs inhibits the area marked with 1 and 2 both?

1. Sacubitril
2. Losartan
3. Nesiritide
4. Omapatrilat
questions.solution:
• The marked arrows indicate a drug that inhibits both ACE and NEP. ACE here refers to Angiotensin Converting Enzyme, and NEP here refers to a neutral endopeptidase called Neprilysin.
  • The drug that inhibits both enzymes is Omapatrilat.
  • Sacubitril is an isolated neprilysin inhibitor
  • Losartan is ARB(Angiotensin receptor blocker)
  • Nesiritide is synthetic natriuretic peptide(BNP)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 536.

choices.text: Hemodialysis for elimination of drug from the body

questions.text: A 24-year male was brought to the emergency due to consumption of 100 tablets of Aspirin. On ABG analysis; pH=7.1; HCO3-= 7 mmol/l. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario presents a medical emergency of acute salicylate (aspirin) poisoning. The ABG parameters reveal metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.36 in the setting of low bicarbonate, often defined as <22 mEq/L).

Thus, the next step in the management of this patient will be the administration of IV sodium bicarbonate to correct acidemia and urinary alkalinization for systemic toxicity to increase aspirin excretion. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 224.

questions.text: A patient is taking anti-gout medications. Which of the following drugs work by inhibiting the synthesis of uric acid?
questions.solution:
• Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and competitively inhibits xanthine oxidase at low concentrations and is a noncompetitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 233.

questions.text: A pregnant female with a history of asthma presented in the 3rd stage of labor. Which drug is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The drug that should be avoided in the prophylaxis of postpartum hemorrhage in this mother with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost as it is a prostaglandin analogue and causes bronchoconstriction. (thus, contraindicated in asthma).
  • Carboprost (15-methyl PGF2α) injected i.m. is an alternative drug for control of PPH due to uterine atony, especially in patients unresponsive to ergometrine and oxytocin.


Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 507, 736.

questions.text: A patient who was on digoxin therapy developed toxicity and the level was 4 ng/ml. How much time would it take to reach the therapeutic PC which is 1 ng/ml? (Given t1/2 = 40 hours)
questions.solution:
Digoxin follows first-order kinetics.

  • In first-order kinetics, Drugs have constant half-lives, irrespective of plasma concentration.
  • Therefore, in first half-life (40 hours) digoxin concentration will fall from 4ng/ml to 2ng/ml.
  • In the next half-life (next 40 hours), the concentration will fall from 2ng/ml to 1ng/ml (desired therapeutic concentration).

Therefore, in 2 half lives i.e. 80 hours therapeutic concentration will be reached.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page. No- 35.

questions.text: A patient had ventricular tachycardia 4 months back. He was given treatment for the same. The patient was on the prescribed drug. The patient now complains of weight gain, dyspnea, dry cough and fatigue. Which of the following drugs is the likely culprit?
questions.solution:
The weight gain and fatigue may indicate thyroid dysfunction leading to hypothyroidism, while the dyspnea and dry cough may occur in the setting of pulmonary fibrosis.
This symptom complex fits the adverse effect profile of amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic.

* Extra Edge: 

  • Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on i.v. injection and after drug cumulation.
  • Nausea, gastrointestinal upset may attend oral medication, especially during the loading phase.
  • Photosensitization and sun burn like skin pigmentation occurs in about 10% patients.
  • Corneal microdeposits (Corneal verticillata) are common with long- term use, may cause headlight dazzle, but are reversible on discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis is the most serious toxicity of prolonged use, but is infrequent if daily dose is kept below 200 mg.
  • Peripheral neuropathy generally manifests as weakness of shoulder and pelvic muscles. Liver damage is rare.
  • Amiodarone interferes with thyroid function in many ways including inhibition of peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and interaction with thyroid hormone receptor. It is a source of iodine as well. Goiter, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism may develop on chronic use.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 576.

choices.text: Candesartan clearance dose should be reduced in hepatic insufficiency but not by renal disease.
Losartan is a competitive antagonist of TXA2 and attenuates platelet aggregation.
Telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal insufficiency but not in hepatic failure.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with hypertension was started on ARB. Which of the following is the true statement?
questions.solution:
Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB).
In addition to its antihypertensive effects, losartan also has antiplatelet activity and can attenuate platelet aggregation by competitively antagonizing thromboxane A2 (TXA2) at its receptor site.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because candesartan clearance is primarily dependent on renal function, and dose adjustment may be necessary in patients with renal impairment, but not in those with hepatic insufficiency.
  • Option 3 is also incorrect because telmisartan is primarily metabolized by the liver and dose adjustment may be necessary in patients with hepatic impairment, but not in those with renal failure.
  • Option 4 Irbesartan doesn't require dose adjustment in renal failure. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 535.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in MI?
questions.solution:
• Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) - Alteplase is a fibrinolytic drug which initiates the fibrinolytic pathway, causing activation of plasminogen (particularly, fibrin-found plasminogen) to plasmin which is responsible for the digestion of fibrin, resulting in the breakdown of clot.
  • The t-PA selectively activates fibrin-bound plasminogen within the thrombus, and any plasmin that leaks is inactivated by circulating antiplasmins.
  • Fibrin bound plasmin is not inactivated by antiplasmins because of common binding site for both fibrin and antiplasmin.
  • The t-PA itself is inactivated by plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 and -2 (PAI-1, PAI-2).



Fig: The plasminogen-plasmin system

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 673.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen in the wet saline mount of vaginal discharge
Cysts can be seen in the wet saline amount of vaginal discharge

questions.text: A female patient presents with pain abdomen and a greenish discharge p/v. Which of these is correct about the causal organism?
questions.solution:
• A female patient presenting with a vaginal discharge and pain in the abdomen with green color discharge is associated with Trichomonas vaginalis infection which shows characteristic jerky or twitching motility in saline mount preparation.
  • The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul smelling frothy vaginal discharge, itching, dysuria and dyspareunia.
  • The gold- standard for diagnosis is Culture on CPLM media. 
  • The treatment of Choice is Metronidazole 2 g orally as a single dose.
     
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 36, 37.

questions.text: Which of the following species is HRP-2 +ve?
questions.solution:
Histidine rich protein-2, abbreviated as HRP-2 is a protozoan antigen, specific to Plasmodium falciparum, the causative agent of cerebral malaria.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 67, 78, 83.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by Clonorchis sinensis?
questions.solution:
Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese or oriental liver fluke) chronic infection with heavy worm burden, can cause mechanical obstruction of the bile duct and irritation due to toxin released by the flukes leads to cholangitis, dilatation of the bile duct, marked ductal epithelial hyperplasia, and fibrosis leading to cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct carcinoma).

Reference: Panikar's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 154, 156.

questions.text: A patient from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer on the leg having rolled edges. On microscopy, dark staining nuclei and kinetoplasts were seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A patient from the western part of Rajasthan, India has an ulcer on the leg (exposed area), with rolled edges, which on microscopy revealed kinetoplasts. This clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous Leishmaniasis.
  • Blood and tissue flagellates including Leishmania and Trypanosoma possess kinetoplasts.



Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 33.40.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, lethargy, and weight loss. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is seen. The blood filarial antigen test was positive. What is the next best step to guide the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's clinical pictures best correlates with occult Filariasis also known as Weingarten's syndrome which represents a hypersensitivity reaction to microfilaria antigen.
  • Since the microfilariae are cleared from the bloodstream, thus, it is unlikely that we shall be able to detect microfilariae in peripheral blood.
  • The confirmation of diagnosis can be done by noting a prompt response to diethylcarbamazine.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 215- 217.

choices.text: Satellitism in the presence of S. aureus

questions.text: A 5-year old patient was brought to the emergency room with high fever, headache and neck rigidity. CSF analysis revealed low sugars, high protein content with leukocytosis. Gram stain revealed pleomorphic gram negative bacilli. CSF culture is likely to show which of the following culture characteristics?
questions.solution:
The scenario depicts gram-negative bacterial meningitis.

  • Haemophilus and Proteus are the two gram-negative bacilli that have a pleomorphic appearance. 
  • Proteus is not known to cause meningitis in children, rather, it causes urinary tract infections. Thus, the most likely causative organism is Haemophilus influenzae. H. influenzae forms large colonies adjacent to the streak line of Staph. aureus, called satellitism - hence option (4) is correct.
Haemophilus Influenzae

It is a fastidious gram-negative bacilli i.e., it requires two factors for its growth:
  1. Factor X is a hemin, present freely in the blood
  2. Factor V is nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), which is present inside RBCs and could be released via hemolysis by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus.
This is responsible for its culture characteristics. When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, factor V is released from S. aureus, and thus, H. influenzae forms large colonies adjacent to the streak line, called satellitism.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 360.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to diagnose Rotavirus?
questions.solution:
• Antigen detection in stool using ELISA/ ICT is a useful test for the detection of Rotavirus infection.
  • VP6 epitopes are the most commonly detected Rotavirus antigens.
  • Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 month of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low grade, fever and temporary lactulose Intolerance.
  • The Antigen enzyme immunoassays and PCRs are used for genotyping of rotavirus nucleic acids from stool specimens.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 546.

questions.text: A person working in gutter holes presented with icterus, fever, and blood in the urine. On examination, conjunctival suffusion is noted. Which of these is useful in the diagnosis of the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
A sewage worker presenting with icteric fever accompanied by hematuria and conjunctival suffusion likely has leptospirosis.

  • The three 3 R's - rodents, rainfall and rice field are important epidemiological exposures.
  • Similar to rice field workers, sewer workers are also at increased risk due to the exposure to rodent-urine infested surroundings, particularly with stagnant water.

The serovar-specific test called microscopic agglutination test, abbreviated as MAT is the gold standard method and the reference test for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 400.

questions.text:
A young female with multiple sexual partners, has vaginal discharge. Gram-staining is shown below. What is the treatment of choice?

1. Ceftriaxone
2. Doxycycline
3. Penicillin
4. Azithromycin
questions.solution:
Answer:(1). Ceftriaxone

The young female with multiple sexual partners and vaginal discharge likely has a sexually transmitted infection.
The image shows microscopic findings of gram-negative intracellular diplococci indicating infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 250.

questions.text: A patient from Delhi presented with high grade fever, and petechiae. CBC report shows a WBC count of 3,000; platelet count is 20,000. The Hb is 11g/ dL. Bleeding time is increased while coagulation time is normal. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
A febrile patient from North India with bleeding manifestations of petechiae, with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia in the presence of a near-normal Hb with increased bleeding time and normal coagulation profile, indicating a quantitative platelet defect, most likely has dengue hemorrhagic fever.
Aedes aegypti is the principal vector followed by Aedes albopictus. They bite during the day time.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 509.

Reference: Hadinegoro SR. The revised WHO dengue case classification: does the system need to be modified? Paediatr Int Child Health. 2012 May;32 Suppl 1(s1):33-8. doi: 10.1179/2046904712Z.00000000052. PMID: 22668448; PMCID: PMC3381438.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Herpes Encephalitis on MRI. Which investigation should be done next?
questions.solution:
• In this patient with encephalitis, a provisional diagnosis of herpes encephalitis is based on neuroimaging by MRI.
  • The gold standard for establishing the diagnosis is the detection of herpes simplex virus DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
  • The T2 weighted MRI of the brain will show Hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in the most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.
  • Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephaliis. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1095.

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with headache, high-grade fever and features suggestive of encephalitis. Bilateral temporal hemorrhages are seen. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
A 25-year old female presents with infectious encephalitis with findings of bilateral temporal hemorrhages.

  • The clue to the etiology arises from the affinity of the pathogen for the temporal lobes, as they are affected bilaterally and there is extensive destruction progressing to hemorrhage.
This correlates most closely with the presentation of HSV-encephalitis, usually caused by HSV-1. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 451.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient presented with cough and dyspnea. CXR showed bilateral lung infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done. GMS staining of the lavage shows black crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
• An immunocompromised HIV-positive patient with respiratory complaints and infiltrates on radiograph with BAL stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain revealing a typical appearance of darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts is classical of Pneumocystis jirovecii.
  • Histopathological examination of lung tissue or fluids obtained by bronchoscopy, bronchial lavage, or open lung biopsy reveals cysts.
  • Gomori's methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black colored crushed ping-pong balls, against the green background. 
  • Pneumocystis is not cultivable and there is no serological test available
  • PCR assay has been developed for detection of P. jirovecii specific genes.
  • Detection of 1, 3 ~-D-glucan in serum.





Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 600.

questions.text: A child presented with a rash, a few days after the onset of fever. The child also has a cough and coryza. On examination of buccal mucosa, Koplik’s spots were seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Koplik’s spots are pathognomonic of measles, and thus, the child is affected by measles virus, an RNA virus, belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family.

Koplik's spots are pathognomonic of measles, appear after two days following fever (i.e. on 12th day of infection) and are characterized by:
  • White to bluish spot (1 mm size) surrounded by an erythema
  • Appear first on buccal mucosa near second lower molars.
  • Rapidly spread to involve the entire buccal mucosa and then fade with the onset of rash.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 485.

questions.text:
An HIV positive patient, with CD4+ counts 160 cells/mm3 presented with a history of fever and weight loss. Ground glass opacities are noted in the lungs.  Bone marrow aspirate is performed, and following findings are obtained. The patient is suffering from?

   
1. Histoplasmosis
2. Coccidioidomycosis
3. Paracoccidioidomycosis
4. Leishmaniasis
questions.solution:
• The immunocompromised patient has constitutional symptoms of fever and weight loss with infiltrates in the lung. The bone marrow aspirate reveals a macrophage cell filled with Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • Clinically, the classical histoplasmosis ranges from asymptomatic infection (in immunocompetent people) to life-threatening illness seen in people with low CMI. The various clinical types include: Pulmonary histoplasmosis: It is the most common form.
  • Acute form presents with mild flu like illness, pulmonary infiltrates in chest X-ray with hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy
  • Chronic cavitary histoplasmosis may be seen in smokers with underlying structural lung disease.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 586.

questions.text: A patient came with a clean, non-lacerated wound. He has received a full course of TT vaccination more than 10 years ago. What will you do now?
questions.solution:
A clean, non-lacerated wound can be categorized as a “not tetanus-prone” wound.

  • In a patient with a previous history of a complete course of TT vaccination taken >10 years back, the appropriate management of this wound shall be to administer a single dose of TT.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 273.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that employs the method of removing cervical, thoracic and abdominal organs from tongue to prostate as a single mass is:
questions.solution:
The “en masse” method of removal of internal organs was originally described by Letulle.

  • Most internal organs are removed in one full swoop.
  • It is a rapid technique for removing the organs from the body although the ensuing dissection is the lengthiest.
  • It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 109.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that is done to limit the spread of infection in HIV patients:
questions.solution:
The in-situ method of dissection, developed by Rokitansky is the method of choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases such as HIV, COVID, Hep B since the organs are dissected in situ with little actual evisceration being performed prior to dissection, avoiding unnecessary exposure to body fluids in the process of evisceration which may transmit the disease.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 109.

questions.text: The temperature of a dead body was found to be 39°C. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
In this case, the temperature of the dead body is found to be raised.

  • This phenomenon is termed postmortem caloricity in which instead of cooling, the temperature of the dead body remains high for approximately the initial 2 hours.
  • Excessive bacterial activity which may occur in septicemia, cholera and other fevers is one of the causes of postmortem caloricity.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 155.

questions.text: A child went out to play and consumed some fruit. Later he presented with confusion, increased body temperature and urine retention. Select the correct option in this case for poisoning and antidote:
questions.solution:
The child has developed the following symptoms after consumption of an unknown fruit:

  • Increased body temperature: Hyperthermia
  • Urinary retention: Sympathetic activation/ Parasympathetic blockade
  • Confusion: Delirium
This likely represents Datura poisoning which may be caused due to the ingestion of the fruit of Datura fastuosa which are spherical and have sharp spines, thus called thorn apples.
The plant contains belladonna alkaloids such as hyoscine whose primary actions are anticholinergic for which the physiological antidote, physostigmine (reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) can be administered to this child along with other supportive measures.

* 8 D's: Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dilated pupils, dry; hot skin, drunken gait, delirium, drowsiness, death due to respiratory failure.

* Treatment:
(1) Emetics can be used.
(2) Washout the stomach repeatedly with a weak solution of tannic acid.
(3) Give activated charcoal and a cathartic.
(4) Wash-out the lower bowel frequently.
(5) Physostigmine one mg., i.v. or i.m., at hourly intervals. In many cases a single dose is sufficient.
(6) Pilocarpine nitrate, 5 mg. s.c. is useful, but it does not counteract action of datura on brain. It can be repeated after two hours.
(7) Morphine is to be avoided because of the danger of depressing the respiratory centre.
(8) Delirium can be controlled by bromides and short acting barbiturates, but ether or chloroform is more beneficial .
(9) Light diet, and free purgation should be carried on for 3 to 4 days to remove the seeds and to increase intestinal motility.
(10) Symptomatic.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 599.

questions.text: A patient presented with seizures, muscle tremors, backward arching of the spine after consuming some ayurvedic medicine. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A patient presents with convulsions, tremors, and opisthotonus, after consumption of herbal medicine due to a neurological poison, likely strychnine.
