  • Mechanism of action: Antagonizes the inhibitory neurotransmitter glycine by blocking its postsynaptic uptake by brainstem and spinal cord receptors
  • Signs and symptoms:
    • Characteristic: ‘Conscious’ seizure (doesn’t cross blood brain barrier)
    • Convulsions: Initially clonic, eventually tonic, affecting all muscles at the same time
    • Risus sardonicus.
    • Opisthotonus, emprosthotonus, pleurothotonus
    • Muscles are completely relaxed in between convulsions
    • Cadaveric spasm

* Extra Edge:
 
  • The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles, so that the body typically arches in hyperextension (opisthotonos).
  • In supine position, the body is supported by the heels and head. The legs are adducted and extended, the arms are flexed over the chest or rigidly extended, and the hands are tightly clenched. The head is bent backwards, and the whole of the body becomes rigid, often assuming a bow-like form.
  • Sometimes, the spasm of the abdominal muscles may bend the body forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleorosthotonos).
  • Consciousness is not lost and the mind remains clear till death.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 613.

questions.text: During harvest season, a farmer was sleeping when he woke up due to a bite. He became drowsy and was brought to the hospital. The wound became red with pain and patient had profuse bleeding. Which of the following was the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The farmer has been bitten by an unidentified animal in the harvest season while sleeping. There is drowsiness with local signs of redness, pain, and continuous bleeding. This is likely to be hemotoxic snake bite envenomation like vipers (ophiotoxaemia).

Viperine bites are characterized by:
  • Severe pain within 8 minutes
  • Onset of swelling within 15 minutes
  • Blood-staining discharge from the wound, with persistent bleeding
  • Blisters in 12 hours in and around the bite site, progressing to involve the entire limb.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 563.

choices.text: Killing mother in an attempt to kill the fetus
Killing of fetus with consent of mother
Killing of fetus without consent of mother
Killing fetus in an attempt to kill the mother amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 of IPC deals with:-
questions.solution:
The legal aspects of criminal abortion are dealt with under sections 312 to 316 of the IPC.

Section 314 of the IPC - death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage:
  • Intent: causing miscarriage of a pregnant woman
  • Act: Causes death of woman (killing of mother); irrespective of whether that offender knew that the act is likely to cause death
  • Punishment: Imprisonment of up to 10 years and fine.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 401.

questions.text: A 10-year old child came with pain in the anal region and a swab was taken from the perineal region, which was subjected to picric acid and showed yellow needle-shaped crystals. Which test was performed?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Barberio’s test

The 10-year old child with anal pain is likely a victim of sexual assault/ sodomy.
For the evaluation of suspected seminal stain, a presumptive chemical test has been performed using picric acid revealing yellow needle-shaped crystals, indicating a positive test. (Barberio’s test)


Fig: A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid when added to spermatic fluid produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 34th Edition, Page. No- 434.

questions.text:
A patient presented with complaints of hearing loss. Rinne’s test using 256 and 512 Hz tuning forks is negative while the test is positive with 1024 Hz tuning fork. What is the air-bone gap in this patient?

1. 0 – 15 dB

2. 15-30 dB

3. 30-45 dB

4. More than 45 dB
questions.solution:
A Rinne's test positive test indicates that air conduction is better than bone conduction, while a negative test indicates the opposite.

  • In this case, the Rinne's test is negative with 256 and 512 Hz tuning forks, but positive with 1024 Hz tuning fork.
  • This indicates that the patient has a conductive hearing loss, as the sound is not being transmitted efficiently through the outer or middle ear to the inner ear.
  • In this case, as the Rinne's test is negative with the lower frequency tuning forks, it suggests that there is a problem with the transmission of sound waves through the outer or middle ear.
  • The positive Rinne's test with the 1024 Hz tuning fork indicates that the inner ear is functioning normally. Therefore, the correct answer is option 3: 30-45 dB, as this range indicates a moderate conductive hearing loss.
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page. No- 26.

questions.text: A patient complains of proptosis of the right eye. There is a history of RTA resulting in head injury 15 years back. There is a homogenous appearance on X-Ray. Orbital cavity fullness is seen on the CT. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with a previous history of head trauma presents with unilateral proptosis.

There is smooth scalloping (characteristic) of its related bony boundaries with erosion & dehiscence of its inferior wall and subsequent encroachment on the right orbital cavity by bulging soft tissue which is seen displacing the right globe downwards, likely causing the proptosis in this patient.
It is seen arising from the frontal paranasal sinus, and is thus, most likely to be a frontal mucocele.
Frontal mucocele presents with headache, proptosis, diplopia. A cystic non tender swelling i noticed with egg shell crackling.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page. No- 231, 289.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The given image represents a view of the nasopharynx as seen during nasoendoscopy. In the first pass (endoscopic evaluation is done using a three-pass technique), the endoscope is passed along the nasal floor visualizing the septum and inferior turbinate, following which we enter the post-nasal space visualizing the eustachian tube, its orifice (option 3) and the Fossa of Rosenmuller.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page. No- 282.

questions.text:
A child has a biphasic stridor on auscultation. The following are the radiographic findings. What is the diagnosis?

 
1. Acute epiglottitis
2. Foreign body
3. Croup
4. Laryngomalacia
questions.solution:
Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis and cervical trachea.
The image shows the AP view of a plain radiograph of the neck of a child showing a ‘steeple sign’ suggestive of croup, also called acute laryngotracheobronchitis which is caused by Parainfluenza Virus.
Management includes- Racemic Epinephrine nebulization, Dexamethasone in leaser invasive route.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page. No- 328.

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive hoarseness and loss of voice, dysphagia and difficulty breathing. The patient has undergone an operation. Identify what procedure has been done.
questions.solution:
The patient with hoarseness progressing to loss of voice, dysphagia and difficulty breathing likely underwent surgical management with a permanent tracheostomy (shown in the image) for laryngeal cancer.

Total laryngectomy:
The entire larynx including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles and one or more rings of trachea are removed. Pharyngeal wall is repaired and lower tracheal stump sutured to the skin for breathing.

Total laryngectomy is indicated in the following conditions:
(i) T3 lesions (i.e. with cord fixed)
(ii) All T4 lesions
(iii) Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
(iv) Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement (v) Lesions of posterior commissure
(vi) Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
(vii) Transglottic cancers, i.e. tumours involving supraglottis and glottis across the ventricle, causing fixation of the vocal cord.
 

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page. No- 351.

questions.text:
A child presented to the OPD with progressive vision loss . It was associated with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis of this child?

1. Congenital glaucoma
2. Mucopolysaccharidosis
3. Retinoblastoma
4. Congenital cataract
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Congenital glaucoma

The child with progressive vision loss, lacrimation, photophobia, and an enlarged, hazy cornea with a frosted-glass appearance/ ground glass appearance as shown in the image has congenital glaucoma.

The examination should include following:
l. Measurement of/OP preferably with hand held Perkin's applanation tonometer or Tonopen should be done since scleral rigidity is very low in children. TOP measurement und e r GA is unpredictably altered.

2. Measurement of corneal diameter by callipers.
3. Slit-lamp examination should be carried out with portable slit-lamp.
4. Ophthalmoscopy to evaluate optic disc.
5. Gonioscopic examination of angle of anterior chamber reveals trabeculo-dysgenesis with either flat or concave iris insertion as described in pathogenesis. Gonioscopy in performed under general anaesthesia using Koeppe's lens for direct visualisation of the angle structures

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 234.

questions.text:
Identify the type of refractive error?

 
1. Myopia
2. Hypermetropia
3. Presbyopia
4. Astigmatism
questions.solution:
Answer: (4). Astigmatism

This image represents the configuration of rays refracted through a toric surface and is called Sturm’s conoid. Focal interval of Sturm refers to the distance between the two foci, B and F.
The horizontal and vertical rays of light converge at different points on the retina due to the irregular shape of the cornea or lens. This condition is known as astigmatism.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 84.

questions.text:
Identify the given picture.

1. Pinguecula
2. Dermoid
3. Dermolipoma
4. Pterygium
questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Dermoid

The given image represents a child with a left-sided skin tag and an ocular lesion present at the limbus, likely a limbal dermoid.
These are common congenital tumours which usually occur at the limbus.
They appear as solid white masses, firmly fixed to the cornea. Dermoid consists of collagenous connective tissue, sebaceous glands and hair, lined by epidermoid Treatment is simple excision.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 96.

questions.text:
A 65 year-old woman patient presented with gradual, painless, progressive vision loss. What is the diagnosis and management of this patient?

1. Immature senile cataract: phacoemulsification with IOL
2. Rosette cataract: restrict glucose intake
3. Sunflower cataract: lens extraction
4. Zonular cataract: lensectomy
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Immature senile cataract

An elderly patient with painless, progressive, gradual diminution of vision is being examined. The pupil is dilated to allow examination of the lens, which reveals wedge-shaped opacifications with an iris shadow.
Triangular spokes of opacity with their apices towards the center are indicative of a cuneiform senile cataract. 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 194.

questions.text: A patient has bilateral right-sided loss of vision. The CT revealed a space occupying lesion. Identify the site of the lesion.
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Left optic tract

The patient with an intracranial space-occupying lesion is experiencing bilateral right-sided vision loss suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.
Here, vision is lost in the right half of both eyes, which means, the lesion affects:
  • Visual field:
    • Left eye: nasal visual field is lost
    • Right eye: temporal visual field is lost
  • Nerve fibers:
    • Left: temporal
    • Right: nasal
Anatomically, this can be explained by the fact that each optic tract contains fibers from the ipsilateral temporal half of the retina and the contralateral nasal half of the retina.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 326.

questions.text:
A 60-year old patient with a defect in both far and near vision hasn't needed to use spectacles for near vision since the last one year. What is the mechanism involved?

  
1. Index myopia
2. Curvatural myopia
3. Axial myopia
4. Positional myopia
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Index myopia

The elderly patient with myopia and hypermetropia (likely, age-related presbyopia) is seen to have a nuclear senile cataract on slit-lamp examination. The patient has been able to read again without the aid of spectacles since last year.
  • When nuclear sclerosis is prominent, the increasing refractive index (thus, index myopia) of the crystalline lens leads to the development of a progressive myopia.
  • As the converging power of the lens increases due to the hardening and inelasticity of the lens, a previously presbyopic patient may be able to read again without the aid of spectacles.
  • This phenomenon of improvement in vision is classically described as ‘second sight.’

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 196.

questions.text:
Which dye and filter are used in the following investigation?

1. Fluorescein, green filter
2. Fluorescein, cobalt filter
3. Lissamine, green filter
4. Lissamine, cobalt filte
questions.solution:
Answer: 2. Fluorescein, cobalt filter

The image given is of a dendritic ulcer seen in herpetic keratitis.
Corneal ulcers can be detected with the help of fluorescein sodium dye and a cobalt-blue filter. The epithelial defect of the cornea appears opaque green with a cobalt blue filter.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 480, 524.

questions.text: A young boy is noted to have a golden color ring over the iris. Which of the following investigations would help you in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: (3). Serum ceruloplasmin

The young boy with a golden color ring visible over the iris may have copper deposition in Descemet’s membrane in Wilson disease, termed Kayser-Fleischer rings. The ring is best seen in Gonioscopy. Penicillamine therapy may cause the ring to disappear.
Low serum Ceruloplasmin is a diagnostic of Wilson's disease.
Another Ocular Finding seen is Anterior capsular Sunflower Cataract.


Reference: Kanski's Clinical ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page No. 267, 301.

questions.text: In a study among two groups of people working in an aniline dye factory, bladder cancer among factory workers is compared to bladder  cancer among office workers for the last 20 years. The past work records are obtained from the offices. What type of study is performed?
questions.solution:
A retrospective cohort study (or "historical" cohort study) is one in which the outcomes have all occurred before the start of the investigation.

  • The investigator goes back in time, sometimes 10 to 30 years, to select his study groups from existing records of past employment, medical or other records and traces them forward through time, from a past date fixed on the records, usually up to the present.
  • This type of study is known by a variety of names : retrospective cohort study, "historical" cohort study, prospective study in retrospect and non-concurrent prospective study.
  • Study time is often of shorter duration because predictor measurements have already been made and documented. In addition, such studies can be less costly and time-consuming than prospective cohort studies. 


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 84.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator to assess the health status of a community and the best predictor of a country’s availability, quality and utilization of primary health services?
questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Infant mortality rate

The infant mortality rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and quality of primary health services, particularly perinatal care.
  • It is the most important indicator of the health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of mother and child health services in general, which are a core component of primary health services.
  • It is one of the universally accepted healthcare indicators for the whole population and the socioeconomic conditions under which they live.


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 622.

choices.text: Years of life lost due to premature death
Years of life lived in poor quality

questions.text: Years of potential life lost is calculated as:
questions.solution:
Answer:(1) Years of life lost due to the premature death

The years of potential life lost (YPLL) can be attributed to the years lost due to premature death. It is a type of mortality indicator which is a measure of premature mortality.
An alternative is to consider the effects of both disability and premature death using disability adjusted life years.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page. No- 26.

choices.text: Isolate for 14 days after the onset of rash, start acyclovir after onset of rash & give VZIG within 72 hours to all contacts
Isolate for 6 days after the onset of rash & give VZIG within within 72 hours to all susceptible contacts
Isolate for 6 days after onset of rash

questions.text: In a hostel, many boys developed multiple rashes over their bodies at different stages with fever. In order to prevent further spread to the students, which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
• An outbreak of fever cases with multiple rashes in different stages of evolution - erythematous macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions is described which points to the diagnosis of chickenpox which has a high-secondary attack rate.
  • Thus, to contain the outbreak, adequate management must be initiated for the cases and contacts.
  • As per guidelines, this would involve isolation of cases for about 6 days with the administration of a live-attenuated vaccine of the Oka strain to all susceptible contacts.
  • VZIG is administered only in Immunosuppressed contacts, hence options (1)(2)(4)are wrong.
High risk Individuals who may benefit from VZIG include:
1. Immunocompromised,
2. Pregnant Women, Newborn whose mothers developed chickenpox within 5 days before delivery.


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page. No- 160.

questions.text: According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Plan, what will be the next step if the sputum smear is negative for AFB but chest X-Ray is highly suggestive of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). CBNAAT

In any clinical setting presumptive patients can be identified by screening for chest symptoms. Some of the patients may walk in with a chest X-ray, if there are some abnormalities in chest X-ray those patients also will be identified as presumptive PTB.
  • These presumptive PTB patients should be subjected for sputum smear microscopy (ZN/FS).
  • Two specimens will be collected (spot-early morning or two supervised spot specimens collected at least one hour apart and smears made from both the samples.
  1. If one or both of the smear is positive, the patient is diagnosed with a microbiologically confirmed Pulmonary TB.
  2. If both of the smears are negative, and the patient is already having a recent chest X-ray suggestive of TB; She/he should be referred for testing to the nearest CBNAAT laboratory, as in this patient.
  3. If both smears are negative and the patient is not having a chest X-ray, s/he should be referred for chest X-Ray. If chest X-ray suggestive of TB, the patient should be referred for CBNAAT.
  4. If the 1st smear is negative and X-Ray is offered in parallel, the second specimen is sent to CBNAAT laboratory (if the X-ray is abnormal).
  5. If both smears are negative and chest X-ray is NOT suggestive of TB and there is strong clinical suspicion of TB, then also the patient needs to be referred for CBNAAT testing.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 202.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a group of people was collected at a young age. Later on, it was found that participants with higher BP at younger ages also have comparatively higher BP at an older age. This is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Blood pressure tracking

The above phenomenon is best described as the "tracking" of blood pressure. The blood pressure of individuals when followed over a period of years from early childhood into adulthood. The BP in individuals with low BP levels tend to remain low, and in those with high BP levels, they tend to remain high. This phenomenon of persistence of rank order of blood pressure has been described as "tracking".



Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 404.

questions.text: The average dietary requirement needed to fulfill the demand of 97.5%of healthy population is known as:
questions.solution:
Answer: 2. Recommended Dietary Allowance

Recommended dietary allowance (RDA) – The RDA is the level of dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the daily nutrient requirements of 97 percent of individuals in a specific life stage group.
It is the average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group. 
RDA presents the level of the nutrient to be consumed daily to meet all the requirements of most of the individuals in a given population. However, it must be recognized that the RDA is not meant to be used as a standard to determine whether or not a given individual requirement has been met, since it is a level above the requirement of most individuals in a given population. RDA value of a nutrient is valid only when all other dietary nutrient intakes are satisfactory.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 689.

choices.text: Collect water coming into the stream to prevent spillage
Collect water from leaking tap is preferable
Collect water after 1 minute of the beginning of flow from the tap
Collect water keeping the collecting tube touching the tap

questions.text: To collect a sample of water for the bacteriological survey from a tap:
questions.solution:
Answer: (1) Collect water coming into the stream to prevent spillage

A sample of water which is to be collected for a bacteriological survey requires careful handling to avoid external contamination. Since the very purpose of collecting the sample is to analyze the sample for microbial contamination, it is understood that precautions taken should be in this direction.
Thus, the following are standard guidelines for such sample collection:
  • The bottle used for sample collection should be:
    • Sterilized
    • Large enough sample volume and additional 2.5 cm headspace to ensure proper sample mixing via shaking
    • Keep bottle closed until just before collecting sample
    • Remove cap and do not set on any surface
    • Avoid external contamination during sample collection
    • Do not contaminate inner surface of stopper/ cap (protected by a parchment or a paper cover)
    • If the water may contain chlorine, add sodium thiosulphate before sterilization
  •  Precautions to avoid contaminating sample:
    • Wear clean disposable gloves when collecting sample
    • Avoid touching bottle mouth with either hands or the faucet tap (option D)
    • Remove any attachments (e.g. water filter) from the tap - these may harbor bacteria that do not reflect the source’s water quality
  • Collection of the sample from a tap:
    • When the sample is taken from a tap in regular use:
      • Tap should be opened fully (cold-water) and let water run to waste long enough to flush the interior of the nozzle and to discharge the stagnant water in the service pipe. This is taken to be at least 2 minutes, and usually 2-3 minutes. (option C)
      • If sampling from a mixed faucet (one where hot and cold water both are mixed) - run hot water for 2 minutes, then cold water for 2-3 minutes and then collect samples.
      • After this the flow of the water is reduced to allow a gentle stream of water from the tap to fill up the tube and avoid splashing.
      • Do not sample from leaking taps as the water will run down the outside of the tap and enter the bottle leading to contamination. (option B)
    • When the sample is taken from a tap which may be contaminated:
      • Disinfect faucet (inside and outside) by applying a sodium hypochlorite solution (100 mg NaClO) to the faucet.
      • Alternatively, a blow lamp or an ignited piece of cotton soaked in methylated spirit may be used to heat the tap and then allow it to cool by letting the water run.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page. No- 823.

questions.text: A pregnant female presented with low vision at night and dryness of eye. During pregnancy she had not taken papaya, mango and several other foods due to fear of these fruits acting as an abortifacient. Which of the following visit home of mother as a part of routine home visit and advise the mothers correctly?
questions.solution:
Answer: 1. ASHA

The pregnant female is experiencing symptoms of night blindness, a feature of Vitamin A deficiency.
Amongst the given options, it is the duty of the ASHA to provide counseling and information to this pregnant patient.

ASHA must be the resident of the village - a woman (married / widow / divorced) preferably in the age group of 25 to 45 years with formal education up to eighth class, having communication skills and leadership qualities. Adequate representation from the disadvantaged population group will ensure to serve such groups better. The general norm of selection is one ASHA for 1000 population. In tribal, hilly and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.
ASHA will make visits to all newborns according to specified schedule up to 42 days of life. The schedule of visit is as follows :
a. Six visits in the case of institutional delivery - Day 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42.
b. Seven visits in the case of home delivery (Day 1, 3 , 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 496.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paresis, signs of UMN paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Beta oxalyl amino alanine

The scenario involves a poor farmer with successive crop failures, with signs of gait dysfunction and signs of UMN disease due to consumption of a toxin, this is likely to be a case of neurolathyrism.
It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/ Lathyrus sativus which contains Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOA) (toxic compound causing lathyrism)
The toxin present in lathyrus seeds has been identified as Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). It has been isolated in crystalline form and is water soluble; this property has been made use of in removing the toxin from the pulse by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soak water. Studies indicate that there is a blood-brain barrier to this toxin. In order to overcome this barrier, the pulse must be eaten in large amounts over a period of time for 2 months or more. Besides BOAA several other toxins have also been reported


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 701.

questions.text: A child studying in class V will receive which of the following under the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Td vaccine

A class V school going student will likely be a nine-to-year old child. The child will be administered the TT/Td vaccine, as per the National Immunization Schedule.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 135.

choices.text: Human resource capacity building in both countries

questions.text: In healthcare, the Colombo Plan is focused on:
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Supplying cobalt therapy units to medical institutions

The Colombo Plan is a regional organization that upholds the concept of a collective intergovernmental effort to strengthen cooperative economic development in South and Southeast Asia.
  • A meeting of the commonwealth foreign ministers with the headquarters at Colombo was held in January 1950.
  • 20 developing countries within the region and 6 non-regional members - Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, the UK, and USA participated.
  • The contribution of Canada in supplying cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India was an important item of the aid under the Colombo plan.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 987.

questions.text: In a village of remote rural areas with poverty, people consume pulses and rice as staple food. Many people presented with spasticity of legs with  crossed lower legs, tip toe walking and walking with sticks. Which of the following can prevent the illness?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Vitamin C

In a poor village with people consuming pulses and rice as staple food suffering from spasticity of legs and gait dysfunction requiring sticks to walk likely suffer from neurolathyrism. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus that contains Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOA).
The condition is believed to be irreversible, in certain cases the damages could be reversed by:
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis: 
    • Daily administration of 500 mg - 1 gram of ascorbic acid for around 7 days
    • The prevention of the damage has also been demonstrated in guinea pigs and monkeys by the generous provision of ascorbic acid in lathyrogenic diet.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 702.

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, irritability and loss of tolerance to heat. Which of the following antibodies is seen in the given disease?
questions.solution:
The patient has heat intolerance associated with diarrhea and irritability.
The image shows a patient with a staring look, likely representing Stellwag’s sign/ Kocher’s sign seen in thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy.
  • Graves’ disease is caused by thyroid stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs) which are synthesized by lymphocytes in the thyroid gland as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes.
  • It is thus characterized as an autoimmune disorder involving the production of autoantibodies against multiple thyroid proteins, most importantly the TSH receptor - TRAb.
  • Lid retraction, causing a staring appearance, can occur in any form of thyrotoxicosis and is the result of sympathetic overactivity.
  • However, Graves’ disease is associated with specific eye signs that comprise Graves’ ophthalmopathy. This condition is also called thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy, because it occurs in the absence of hyperthyroidism in 10% of patients.
  • Most of these individuals have autoimmune hypothyroidism or thyroid antibodies. The onset of Graves’ ophthalmopathy occurs within the year before or after the diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis in 75% of patients but can sometimes precede or follow thyrotoxicosis by several years, accounting for some cases of euthyroid ophthalmopathy.

* The “NO SPECS” scoring system to evaluate ophthalmopathy is an acronym derived from the following changes:
0 = No signs or symptoms
1 = Only signs (lid retraction or lag), no symptoms
2 = Soft tissue involvement (periorbital edema)
3 = Proptosis (>22 mm)
4 = Extraocular muscle involvement (diplopia)
5 = Corneal involvement
6 = Sight loss

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2939.

questions.text: What is the cause of the following murmur?
questions.solution:
The given image is representative of the phonocardiogram (PCG) tracing obtained in a patient. The murmur represented is a holosystolic murmur i.e. lying between the first and second heart sounds, with equal intensities of S1 and S2.
The murmur of mitral regurgitation is often described as a holosystolic, high-pitched, “blowing murmur” which is loudest at the apex and radiates towards the axilla. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1997.

questions.text: ECG of a patient is given. Which of the following can lead to the ECG changes shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient reveals tall, symmetrically peaked T waves. Based on the options, the patient is likely being managed with antihypertensives.
The finding of peaked/ tall T waves can be due to hyperkalemia, and in this patient it is likely to be medication-induced, the likely culprit being spironolactone.
Spironolactone is a potassium Sparing Diuretic. It is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of kidneys. as a result, Spironolactone Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 348.

questions.text: A 78-year old lady was brought to the OPD with complaints of progressive difficulty in daily activities for 6 months, Convulsions and visual hallucinations. The patient is reported to stare calmly and continuously at the sky. The autopsy of the patient revealed Lewy bodies. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Lewy body disease, which is the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia, after Alzheimer’s disease.
  • One may have even considered PDD (i.e. Parkinson disease dementia) a suitable answer as it is part of the spectrum of Lewy body disease.
  • Based on this premise, and exclusion of other options, Parkinson's disease (PD) has been chosen as the single-best answer.
  • Please note PDD and PD are distinct conditions but approximately 10% of patients with PD develop PDD per year, with the majority of PD patients developing PDD over time.
* Diagnosis: 
  • The key neuropathologic feature in LBD is the presence of Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites throughout specific brainstem nuclei, substantia nigra, amygdala, cingulate gyrus, and, ultimately, the neocortex.
  • Lewy bodies are intraneuronal cytoplasmic inclusions that stain with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) and ubiquitin but are now identified with antibodies to the presynaptic protein α-synuclein.
  • Lewy bodies are composed of straight neurofilaments 7–20 nm long with surrounding amorphous material and contain epitopes recognized by antibodies against phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated neurofilament proteins, ubiquitin, and α-synuclein.
  • The presence of α-synuclein aggregates in neurons and glia in PDD and DLB molecularly classifies these diseases as synucleinopathies.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3385.

questions.text: A 45-year old alcoholic male patient presented with pain in the great toe. The synovial aspirate revealed increased WBCs. Serum uric acid levels are found to be normal. There is no history of fever, dysuria or diarrhea. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case is acute gouty arthritis, which is supported by the patient's symptoms and the synovial aspirate showing increased white blood cells.
  • Gout is a type of arthritis that occurs when uric acid crystals accumulate in the joints, leading to inflammation and pain.
  • However, it is worth noting that the normal serum uric acid levels do not completely rule out the possibility of gout, as some individuals with gout may have normal uric acid levels.
  • Although nonpharmacologic measures, such as ice pack application and rest of the involved joints, can be helpful, the mainstay of acute gout care is the administration of anti-inflammatory drugs such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, and glucocorticoids.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2896.

questions.text: A 51-year old female presented with palpitation, chest discomfort and fatigue. Auscultation reveals a mid-diastolic murmur. The JVP tracing shows large ‘a’ waves. The patient most likely will have?
questions.solution:
The patient with a mid-diastolic murmur and giant ‘a’ waves has a valvular heart lesion - tricuspid stenosis which is the cause of the patient’s difficulty in breathing.
The patient most likely has tricuspid stenosis.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1817.

questions.text:
A 50-year old man who is a chronic smoker has a cough with hemoptysis. He complains of shooting pain in the right arm. The patient is noted to have ptosis. Chest X-Ray findings are as shown. What is the diagnosis?

1. SVC syndrome
2. Pancoast tumor
3. Thyroid cancer
4. Aspergilloma
questions.solution:
A chronic smoker with hemoptysis, ptosis, and unilateral pain in the arm with CXR revealing a right upper lobe mass likely has a Pancoast tumor/ superior sulcus tumor. 
  • The central or endobronchial growth of the tumor is responsible for the cough and hemoptysis and suggests a diagnosis of lung cancer.
  • Superior sulcus tumors represent a distinctive subset of stage III disease. These tumors arise in the apex of the lung and may invade the second and third ribs, the brachial plexus, the subclavian vessels, the stellate ganglion, and adjacent vertebral bodies.
  • They also may be associated with Pancoast syndrome, characterized by pain that may arise in the shoulder or chest wall or radiate to the neck. Pain characteristically radiates to the ulnar surface of the hand.
  • Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) due to invasion of the paravertebral sympathetic chain may be present as well. Patients with these tumors should undergo the same staging procedures as all patients with stage II and III NSCLC.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy or combined chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery is reserved for those without N2 involvement.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 606.

questions.text: A patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, fatigue and jaundice. The patient is found to be HBsAg +ve and HBeAg +ve. Serum ALT levels are >2 times normal. HBV DNA is >104. USG reveals coarsened hepatic echotexture and no other abnormalities. What treatment should be initiated for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases (AASLD) lays down the guidelines for the management of chronic hepatitis B based on HBeAg status, clinical picture, HBV DNA, and ALT levels.
 
  • The patient with cirrhosis, with no features of decompensation, with HBV DNA levels > 2 x 103 should be treated with oral agents, and not PEG IFN, as it is avoided in patients with cirrhosis, transplantation, or immunosuppressed. (option 1)
 
  • Lamivudine is no longer preferred for the treatment of chronic hepatitis, due to the high rate of drug resistance. (option 3, option 4)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2566, 2567.

choices.text: The threshold of plasma osmolality is lowered transiently and no treatment is require
She has DI and require DDAVP life long
She has DI and require DDAVP for a few weeks and stop after that

questions.text: A 14-year old girl underwent resection of a large pituitary lesion, and developed polyuria. Urine osmolarity was seen to be 100 mOsm and serum Na+ was 155 mEq/ L. Which is correct about the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggesting central diabetes insipidus in a neurosurgical patient.
The diagnosis is made by the presence of the classic triad (as seen in this patient) of:
  • Polyuria
  • Hypernatremia as evidenced by raised serum Na+ levels
  • Dilute urine as evidenced by low urine osmolality
* Management principles:
  1. If the duration of diabetes insipidus is quite transient, it is acceptable to treat this simply with fluid replacement, parenterally or orally.
  2. However, most patients who develop diabetes insipidus require desmopressin 0.5 to 2 μg subcutaneously, intramuscularly, or intravenously for life.
  3. Periodic drug discontinuation allows for assessing whether or not it is still required. Thus, the best answer would be to give a trial of desmopressin and continue monitoring the patient for a few weeks.
Thiazides have a role in the management of nephrogenic DI. (option D)

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2920, 2921.

questions.text: A young female presents with cheilitis. On examination, there is pallor, loss of proprioception and touch, absent ankle reflex, UMN type of lower limb weakness. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The female patient with cheilitis, anemia and neurological manifestations likely has vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Anemia and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord are the two major disease manifestations of this nutritional deficiency.
  • Subacute refers to the neurological disease course, while combined refers to the involvement of both the sensory (dorsal column) and motor (lateral corticospinal tract) in addition to the spinocerebellar tracts, and leads to the characteristic findings as seen in this patient.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3454.

questions.text: A female patient presents with restlessness, palpitations and tremors. BP is recorded to be 180/110 along with tachycardia. On examination there is a neck swelling. She is a known case of asthma. ECG shows A-Fib. Which drug is used next in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A female asthmatic patient with a neck swelling and symptoms of restlessness, palpitations and tremors with increased blood pressure and heart rate, showing atrial fibrillation on ECG has multiple issues:
  • Asthma
  • Hyperthyroidism as indicated by the neck swelling, restlessness, palpitations, tremors, increased heart rate and BP (with a high index of suspicion for thyroid storm/ crisis, particularly if the patient has hyperpyrexia or is agitated)
  • Atrial fibrillation - precipitated by the thyrotoxicosis
The first step in the management of atrial fibrillation, despite the cause, is to control the ventricular response. Beta-adrenergic blockers, calcium channel blockers and digoxin are effective agents. 
In patients with severe asthma in whom beta blockers are contraindicated, rate control can be achieved with calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2942.

questions.text: Usually patients of CKD develop hyperkalemia. Patients refractory to pharmacological measures are treated with hemodialysis. But, dialysis in these patients may lead to headache, nausea, vomiting, CNS disturbances and even convulsions, called Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) is characterized by a range of neurologic symptoms that affect patients on hemodialysis, particularly when they are first started on dialysis.

As Hemodialysis rapidly removes small solutes such as urea leading to rapid decline in the blood urea.
This decline in patients who have marked azotemia acutely and significantly lowers plasma osmolality, thereby creating a transient osmotic gradient between plasma and brain cells. This gradient leads to water shift into neurons that produces cerebral edema.
  • Among patients who develop DDS, we initially review the delivered dialysis prescription and quickly initiate sodium modeling.
  • If clinical improvement is not noted within 30 minutes, the patient is taken off dialysis.
  • Among patients with persistent severe DDS (such as seizures, encephalopathy, or coma) despite the use of sodium modeling - a trial of hypertonic saline or mannitol may be given to prevent further osmotic shifts and tackle the development of cerebral edema.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2323.

questions.text: An IT Engineer patient present with complaints of hematemesis and melena. He has a history of epigastric pain intermittently for a long period of time. He takes alcohol occasionally. He is currently taking aspirin for his arthritis.What is the cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient with a history of intermittent gastric pain with:
  • Consumption of alcohol
  • NSAID intake and
  • A stressful lifestyle (IT engineer)
The patient develops hematemesis and melena, features of upper GI bleeding. In light of multiple risk factors and clinical presentation, the patient most likely has peptic ulcer disease.
Peptic ulcers are the most common cause of upper GI bleeding and UGIB is the most common complication of peptic ulcer disease.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1153, 1206.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with vague RUQ pain and weight loss. The AST and ALT levels are normal, ALP levels are 200 and direct bilirubin is 1 mg. The AFP levels are raised. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with a history of alcohol dependence, unintentional weight loss, normal transaminases and raised AFP most likely has hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common cause of a primary liver malignancy in adults.
The features are as follows:
  • More commonly seen in males
  • Peak age group is 7th decade of life
  • Risk factors for HCC are:
    • Cirrhosis and associated chronic liver damage due to:
      • Chronic infection by hepatitis B or C virus (HBV or HCV)
      • Alcohol abuse
      • Metabolic syndrome
      • Hemochromatosis.
Management:
  • Very early HCC: Ablation
  • Early HCC:
    • Single nodule: Resected
    • Multiple nodules over 3 cm: Ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate-stage HCC: Chemoembolization.
    • Transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) is used for multinodular lesions.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 681.

questions.text: A patient planned for surgery is to be given neoadjuvant chemotherapy. What is meant by neoadjuvant chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Preoperative, or “neoadjuvant,” treatment involves the administration of adjuvant systemic therapy, most commonly chemotherapy, before definitive surgery and radiation therapy.
The objective of neoadjuvant chemotherapy is to reduce the bulk of the tumor.
Treatment given as a first step to shrink a tumor before the main treatment, which is usually surgery, is given. Examples of neoadjuvant therapy include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. It is a type of induction therapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 208, 933.

choices.text: Angiogram to find the site of aneurysm

questions.text: A female patient who is a hypertensive presented with a sudden onset headache. BP is 160/ 100 mmHg. CT shows SAH. What is the next initial step in the management?
questions.solution:
The hypertensive female with sudden headache, BP of 160/100 mmHg with no history of trauma was diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage on non-contrast CT of the head.
This Spontaneous SAH likely indicates a case of aneurysmal SAH. 
Once a diagnosis of SAH has been made, the etiology of the hemorrhage must be determined with angiographic studies. This may be done using:
  1. Conventional digital subtraction angiography (DSA)
  2. Computed tomography angiography (CTA)
  3. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 367, 709.

questions.text:
A retroviral patient with CD4 counts CD4 count = 36 cells/mm3 was evaluated with a radiograph which revealed bilateral nodular opacities in the lung fields. Sputum CBNAAT was found to be negative. The patient presents to the clinic with the following lesions on the face and thorax, and is initiated on ART. What is the most probable diagnosis?

1. Disseminated TB infection
2. Dissemination cryptococcus infection
3. Disseminated histoplasmosis
4. Disseminated molluscum contagiosum
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • Progressive disseminated histoplasmosis(PDH) is seen in immunocompromised patients.
  • Common risk factors are AIDS(CD4+ T-cell count,<200/μL) extremes of age, the administration of immunosuppressive drugs(e.g., prednisone, mycophenolate, calcineurin inhibitors),and use of drugs like methotrexate, anti-TNF-a agents, and other biologic response modifiers for autoimmune disorders. It most commonly involves the lungs and bone marrow.
  • The clinical spectrum of PDH ranges from an acute, rapidly fatal course—with diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular lung infiltrates causing respiratory failure, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure—to a subacute or chronic course with a focal organ distribution.
  • Common manifestations include fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Other findings may include meningitis or focal brain lesions, ulcerations of the oral mucosa, gastrointestinal ulcerations and bleeding, and adrenal insufficiency. Prompt recognition of this devastating illness is of paramount importance in patients with severe manifestations or with underlying immunosuppression, especially that due to AIDS.

Fig: Intracellular yeasts (arrows) of H. capsulatum in a liver biopsy specimen (hematoxylin and eosin stain) from a patient who developed progressive disseminated histoplasmosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1658.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient presented to a hospital where the attending intern wanted to assess the qSOFA score. What are the components of the score?
questions.solution:
qSOFA score refer to the quick Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment score.
Components of qSOFA:
  • Altered mentation (GCS <15)
  • Systolic blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)
  • Respiratory rate (RR > 22 breaths/ minute)
    • Suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when: > 2 out of 3 parameters are present (qSOFA +ve).
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 63.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pancreatitis presents with recurrent attacks of pain in the abdomen. The main duct diameter is found to be 10 mm with intraductal calculi. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient with chronic pancreatitis with intractable abdominal pain not relieved by first-line medical management is a candidate for surgical management.
  • The patients with a dilated MPD have obstructive pancreatopathy and the pain is attributed to the ductal hypertension, thus, these patients would benefit from a drainage procedure - in this patient the lateral or longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LPJ) called the modified Puestow procedure.
  • Pancreatic duct dilation is defined as a main pancreatic duct measuring at least 7 mm in diameter. Pancreatic duct dilation can be secondary to a single stone or stricture; however, it is often caused by multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. The pancreatic duct dilation observed on pancreatography for chronic pancreatitis is classically described as a chain of lakes, which reflects the presence of multiple dilations and stenoses. When it is accompanied by intractable pain, this condition is best treated with side-to-side Rouxen-Y pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the modified Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1545.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of surgery presents with the following finding at the scar site. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
The patient with the previous history of surgery has inspection findings of a large area of scar tissue which has failed to regress within a year and expands beyond the boundaries of the original wound margins, suggestive of a keloid.
If the scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress, it is called a keloid. Keloid formation seems to be an individual predisposition, and for unknown reasons it is somewhat more common in African Americans.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 110.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient on examination was opening eyes to pain, speaking inappropriate words and withdrawing from pain. What is his GCS score?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used as an objective clinical measure of the severity of brain injury.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2218.

choices.text: It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: Patient presented with a clinical picture as shown. Surgical debridement is done for the patient. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with a necrotizing soft tissue infection of the perineal region ( Fournier’s gangrene) has undergone surgical debridement.
Diabetes mellitus and immunosuppression are associated risk factors.
It is a surgical emergency.
Treatment involves a combination of:
  1. Extensive surgical debridement: for source control, as already done in this patient. It is the cornerstone of treatment.

  2. Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics: Initiated as soon as possible. intent of covering gram positives (including MRSA), gram negatives, and anaerobic organisms, since, most commonly it is caused by a polymicrobial flora including gram positive cocci, gram-negative rods, and anaerobic bacteria including Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp, Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus.

Since the blood supply of the testicles is from the testicular artery and independent of the overlying tissue it is usually not infected. Thus bilateral orchiectomy is generally not required. (option B)
Urinary or fecal diversion may be necessary depending on the location and degree of tissue loss but is seldom necessary at the initial debridement, and will not be the next step in the management of this patient. (option C)
Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is of historical importance in the treatment of gas gangrene and is no longer used. (option D)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 1510.

questions.text: A patient complains of diarrhea 1 week back followed by right upper quadrant pain and fever. Imaging reveals a 75 cc liver abscess. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient with a liver abscess with clinical symptoms of RUQ pain and fever with an antecedent history of diarrhea likely has amebic liver abscess.
Medical treatment is very effective and should be the first choice in the elective situation.
Metronidazole 750 mg three times a day for 7 to 10 days is the treatment of choice.
Patients respond dramatically within 72 hours.

Aspiration (percutaneous needle aspiration) or percutaneous (catheter) drainage (also done under metronidazole cover) are indicated in cases where there is: (option D)
  • Diagnostic uncertainty: to rule out pyogenic abscess
  • Lack of response in 3-5 days to medical management
  • Imminent rupture
  • Prevent rupture of left-lobe abscesses into the pericardium. (Percutaneous drainage may be successful even if the liver abscess has already ruptured)
  • There is no evidence that aspiration, even of large abscesses (up to 10 cm), accelerates healing.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1456, 1457.

questions.text: A patient consumed a liquid containing 90% NaOH and has absolute dysphagia. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Nasogastric/duodenal tube is placed under endoscopic guidance for alimentary nutritional support in patients with chemical injury to esophagus.
However, in this patient with ingestion of 90% alkali, there is likely transmural necrosis of esophagus and stomach both, thus this patient will require a feeding jejunostomy for nutrition.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 411.

questions.text: A patient presented with vague RUQ pain, fever, chills and icterus. Radiology reveals the following. Which is correct about the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with fever, chills, RUQ pain and icterus likely has an infectious pathology of the liver.
Cross-sectional slice on CT reveals hypodense lesions with a distinct wall.
  • Laminated, serpentine, linear membranes are visible inside the larger pericyst. This is called the serpent sign or snake sign, indicating hydatid disease of the liver.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog (definitive host) tapeworm.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1460.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing abdominoperineal resection. Which of the following is likely to be seen after the ligation of the first vessel of the surgery?
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing an abdominal perineal resection (APR), also called the Miles procedure, which includes the resection of the sigmoid colon, rectum, and anus and the construction of a permanent end colostomy.
In the abdominal part of the procedure, the inferior mesenteric artery is the first vessel to be ligated.
The pelvic sympathetic nerves are prone to get injured at their origin from the aortic plexus; during high ligation of the IMA leading to:
  • In men: Retrograde ejaculation (option D)
  • Urinary dysfunction: Sympathetic innervation to the bladder neck, trigone, and urethra.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1329, 1385.

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of laparoscopic surgery over open surgery except?
questions.solution:
Following are the advantages of laparoscopic surgery: 
  1. Less post-operative pain
  2. Better cosmesis
  3. Shorter hospital stay
  4. Early recovery
  5. less intraoperative adhesions
  6. Better anatomy perception (as image can be magnified)- early recognition of burns if any.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 103.

questions.text: The following finding was observed. Identify?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point on the plantar surface, most likely that of a trophic ulcer/ neuropathic ulcer.
A neuropathic ulcer is a result of peripheral neuropathy due to lack of sensation over the pressure points leading to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.
Features of a neuropathic ulcer include:
  • Painless (due to lack of sensation)
  • Margins: Regular; Punched-out appearance; Presence of calluses on the margin
  • Location: Plantar surface of foot
The following causes of leg ulceration are important differential diagnoses:
  • Arterial/ ischaemic ulcers (option A)
    • Pale/ necrotic
    • Skin changes: shiny, loss of hair
    • Over joints and bony prominences
  • Venous leg ulcer (option B)
    • Gently sloping edge
    • Floor: Granulation tissue
    • Location: Gaiter region (between muscles of calf and ankle)
  • Neuropathic ulcers/ trophic ulcers
  • Neoplastic ulcers/ malignant ulcers (option D)
    • Elevation of the ulcer edge (overturned edges)
    • Requires biopsy to exclude squamous cell carcinoma
  • Infections (example - tuberculosis)
  • Vasculitic ulcers
  • Traumatic ulcers

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 111.

questions.text: A 20-year old male presents with a midline neck swelling that moves with protrusion of tongue. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The young male patient presents with a midline cervical swelling which moves on protrusion of the tongue.
This is likely to be a thyroglossal duct cyst.
  • The normal development and subsequent obliteration of the thyroglossal duct are connected to that of the hyoid bone, which forms starting at the seventh week of gestation and functionally divides the thyroglossal tract into superior and inferior aspects.
  • When the thyroglossal duct does not completely obliterate and the epithelial duct cells remain, a thyroglossal duct cyst may arise from a persistent connection between the thyroid gland and the foramen cecum.
  • This scenario typically presents as a painless midline neck mass at or near the level of the hyoid, although it can be found near the base of the tongue or at the thyroid gland proper. Occasionally, these cysts can become infected from oral bacteria from the tongue, and can also form fistulous sinuses to the skin.

 * Management: 

The Sistrunk procedure, originally described in 1920, is the surgical treatment of choice for thyroglossal duct cysts that become chronically infected.
A number of modifications have been described, but the key component of the procedure involves excision of the entirety of the cyst and surrounding thyroglossal duct tract, including the central portion of the hyoid bone.
Resection of a small portion of the tongue is no longer thought to be necessary in the majority of cases.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 875.

questions.text: A patient presented with a red, dense, mobile, nodular swelling with a variable consistency below the ear lobule from the last 2 years as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with a retromandibular swelling as shown in the image likely has a parotid neoplasm.
Most benign tumors will be smooth, relatively mobile and painless to palpate.
The patient complains of a mass behind the angle of their jaw in the retromandibular region, in front of the tragus or in the cheek.
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 789.

questions.text: An adult diabetic patient complains of pain over the gluteal region on sitting and after 24 hours develops discharge from behind the scrotum and undergoes surgical debridement extending deep to the fascia. Black necrotic material was removed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This rapidly progressive fasciitis of the genitalia and perineum represents Fournier’s gangrene, a type of necrotizing fasciitis, a necrotizing soft tissue infection.
The infection is often polymicrobial and spreads along dartos, Scarpa’s, and Colles’ fascia.
Risk factors include:
  • Perirectal abscesses
  • Diabetes and obesity
  • Chronic alcoholism
Fournier gangrene is a necrotizing infection of the male genital and perineal skin and subcutaneous tissues, similar to other progressive fasciitis and necrotizing soft tissue infections. When the genitalia are involved, patients typically present with significant pain and tenderness, scrotal and genital swelling, discoloration or frank necrosis, crepitus, and, at times, foul-smelling discharge. Fournier gangrene is usually a polymicrobial infection with microaerobes, anaerobes, and gram-positive and gram-negative organisms.

Treatment requires urgent surgical drainage with aggressive debridement of the necrotic tissue, broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and intensive monitoring with supportive care. The magnitude of the debridement depends entirely on the degree of progression of the process.
It is rare for the process to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis deep to the tunica vaginalis and Buck fascia, respectively, so these structures should be preserved. It is uncommon for the urethra to be involved, although a defined urinary tract source may be evident, such as a urethral stricture, with perforation and local infection.



Fig: Fournier gangrene. Skin necrosis, purulence, and edema of the scrotum.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 2067.

choices.text: It is a case of Meleney’s gangrene
Hyperbaric O2 therapy does not reduce mortality

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect regarding the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
This likely represents synergistic spreading gangrene, also termed subdermal gangrene or necrotizing fasciitis.
  • Abdominal wall infections are known as Meleney’s synergistic gangrene and scrotal infections as Fournier’s gangrene. (option A)
  • Recently, the role of hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) has become more established with a reduction in mortality in patients treated with HBO (9–20%) compared with patients who did not receive HBO (30–50%).
  • This lesion harbors Staphylococcus aureus and an anaerobic streptococcus, and is thus a polymicrobial pattern of infection with aerobes and anaerobes. (option B)
  • Surgical debridement of the necrotic tissue is the cornerstone of management. This process is repeated daily as the necrosis is prone to spread beyond the edges of the excised wound. (option D)
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 140.

questions.text: A patient present with acute chest pain radiating to the back and interscapular area. On chest X-Ray, widening of mediastinum is seen. BP in the left arm is 160/ 100 mmHg and right arm is 100/60 mm Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute chest pain radiating to the interscapular area with a widened mediastinum and an inter-arm difference in blood pressure (IADBP) with left > right, alerting the possibility of aortic dissection.
Clinical features and diagnosis of aortic dissection:
  • Characteristics of pain:
    • Site: Localized to the front or back of the chest, often the interscapular region
    • Onset: Sudden
    • Character: Tearing
    • Radiation: Typically migrates with propagation of the dissection
    • Associations: Diaphoresis
    • Severity: Very severe
  • CXR findings
    • Ascending aorta: widened superior mediastinum.
    • Descending thoracic aorta: a widened mediastinum; the descending aorta appears wider than ascending aorta
  • Diagnosis: CT

Fig: De Bakey (left) and Stanford (right) aortic dissection classifications

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1752.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic bilateral inguinal surgery with entrapment of nerve. The patient presents with pain in the lower limb. Which is the injured nerve?
questions.solution:
The patient has presented with lower limb pain post laparoscopic bilateral inguinal surgery.
This is most likely due to entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve resulting in meralgia paresthetica.
Pain after inguinal hernia repair is classified into acute or chronic manifestations of three mechanisms:
  • Nociceptive (somatic): most common
  • Neuropathic:
    • Direct nerve damage
    • Entrapment (as in this patient)
  • Visceral pain: may occur during ejaculation as a result of sympathetic plexus injury
The nerves injured in laparoscopic repair are:
  1. Genitofemoral nerve
  2. Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1119.

questions.text: The following growth is seen on the retraction of prepuce of the patient. Inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a warty growth that is visible on retraction of the prepuce, representing penile carcinoma involving the glans with no inguinal lymphadenopathy on clinical examination.
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type and it most commonly originates from the glans. 
  • Lesions involving glans or distal shaft require partial penectomy with 2 cm margin.
  • This may be accompanied by bilateral ilioinguinal LN dissection in case the patient has metastatic lymph nodes.
  • Small non-invasive lesions (penile intraepithelial neoplasia) involving prepuce can be managed by 5-fluorouracil cream, CO2 laser ablation, Nd-YAG laser and radiotherapy but require close follow-up. Wide excision or circumcision may also be required. (option A, option B)
  • If the lesion involves proximal shaft or a 2 cm margin is not achievable, total penectomy with perineal urethrostomy is done. (option D)
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 1553.

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been doing this job for a long time, but the symptoms are recent in onset. What is the likely mechanism involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
Raynaud’s syndrome may follow the use of vibrating tools.
Thus, it is a recognised industrial disease and is known as ‘vibration white finger’ or vibration Raynaud syndrome/ hand-arm vibration syndrome.
  • Direct damage to vessels and neural dysfunction is implicated in vibration-induced RP.
  • Raynaud’s syndrome occurs due to peripheral vasospasm (abnormal thermoregulatory response by sympathetic nervous system) and is more common in the upper extremities.
It may occur due to exposure to the following:
  • Cold temperatures
  • Tobacco
  • Emotional stress
  • Occupation groups: Vibrating tools
  • Raynaud phenomenon: secondary to scleroderma, SLE, Sjogren’s and APLA
The characteristic changes are as follows:
  • Intense pallor (white attack)
  • Cyanosis (blue attack)
  • Reactive hyperemia
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 2112.

questions.text: A patient of varicose veins developed eczema around the veins. What is the CEAP classification of this patient?
questions.solution:
The Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification is a method to categorize chronic venous disorders for standardized reporting. The visible signs of chronic venous disorders are categorized as C0 to C6 depending on appearance
  • C1: Presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2 classification refers to varicose veins: subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins > 3 mm in diameter (option A)
  • C3 refers to edema: when associated with venous reflux, it is characterized by the development of dependent ankle edema (option B)
  • C4a refers to skin pigmentation/ dermatitis/ eczema: as seen in this patient (option 3)
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 974.

choices.text: Weight under 75th centile and height under 25th centile

questions.text: Adequate nutritional status in an infant with birth weight of 2.8 kg is assessed by:
questions.solution:
The normal pattern of growth generally implies an average of readings obtained in a group of healthy individuals, along with a permissible range of variation between the 3rd and 97th percentiles. (option C)
  • The average birth weight of Indian neonates is about 3 kg.
  • After initial loss of extracellular fluid over the first few days, infants regain their birth weight by 10 days of life.
  • For the first three months, they gain approximately 20-40 g per day.
  • For the remaining year, they gain about 400 g of weight every month. (option B)
  • The infant measures approximately 50 cm at birth, and about 75 cm at one year of life. This corresponds to an increase in about 25 cm in the 1st year of life.
  • The anterior fontanelle closes by 18 months of age. (option D)


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 151, 3055.

questions.text: A baby born with prematurity, has low birth weight, decreased hearing, bilateral cataract and PDA. What is the most likely cause ?
questions.solution:
The premature LBW child has deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus), the classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome.
  • The classic triad of CRS—clinical manifestations of cataracts, hearing impairment, and heart defects—is seen in ~10% of infants with CRS. Infants may present with different combinations of defects depending on when infection occurs during gestation. Hearing impairment is the most common single defect of CRS.
  • However, as with acquired rubella, laboratory diagnosis of congenital infection is highly recommended, particularly because most features of the clinical presentation are nonspecific and may be associated with other intrauterine infections.
  • Early diagnosis of CRS allows the prompt implementation of infection control measures and facilitates appropriate medical intervention for specific disabilities.
  • Diagnostic tests used to confirm CRS include serologic assays and virus detection. In an infant with congenital infection, serum IgM antibodies are normally present for up to 6 months but may be detectable for up to 1 year after birth.
  • In some instances, IgM may not be detectable until 1 month of age; thus, infants who have symptoms consistent with CRS but who test negative shortly after birth should be retested at 1 month.
  • A rubella serum IgG titer persisting beyond the time expected after passive transfer of maternal IgG antibody (i.e., a rubella titer that does not decline at the expected rate of a twofold dilution per month) is another serologic criterion used to confirm CRS.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1613.

questions.text:
A 2-month old infant presented with progressive jaundice. The infant has raised direct bilirubin levels and the stools are pale-colored. Lab Investigations Revealed that baby has Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia. Liver biopsy showed bile plugs and bile duct proliferation with a polymorphonuclear infiltrate. What is the most common cause?
1, Dubin-Johnson syndrome
2. Crigler-Najjar syndrome
3. Extrahepatic biliary atresia
4. Gilbert syndrome
questions.solution:
The infant has jaundice due to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with pale-colored stools suggesting neonatal cholestasis (conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in first 3 months of life).
In such non-sick infants with pale stools, the main objective is to rule out biliary atresia (most common cause of neonatal cholestasis), and a liver biopsy showing bile duct proliferation with plugging and inflammation is suggestive of Biliary atresia in such cases.
 
  • In Dubin Johnson syndrome, liver biopsy reveals brown-black pigmentation. (option A)
  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome are genetic causes of unconjugated/ indirect hyperbilirubinemia occurring due to deficiency of enzymes responsible for conjugation of bilirubin. (option B, option D)
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 2099, 2103.

questions.text: Sweat chloride levels are measured for which disease?
questions.solution:
Demonstration of high sweat-chloride levels (>60 mEq/ L) on at least two occasions is used for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.
 
  • Serum levels can be used to diagnose antitrypsin deficiency. (option B)
  • Iron studies, liver function testing and HFE gene testing can be used in the evaluation of hereditary hemochromatosis. (option C)
  • Serum ceruloplasmin level, slit lamp eye examination and 24-hour urinary copper excretion are part of the initial workup for Wilson’s disease. (option D)
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 695, 2288.

choices.text: Initial ABC resuscitation and 10 mL/ Kg 0.9% IV Bolus NaCl with insulin 0.1 IU/ Kg/ hr
Initial ABC resuscitation and 15 mL/ Kg 0.9% IV Bolus NaCl then insulin 0.1 IU/ Kg/ hr
Initial ABC resuscitation and 25 mL/ Kg 0.9% IV Bolus NaCl with insulin 0.1 IU/ Kg/ hr

questions.text: A 10-year old child, weighing 30 Kg presents with loose stools for the last 2 days and vomiting causing decreased peripheral perfusion with cold clammy extremities and delayed capillary refill. pH is noted to be 7.1, blood glucose is 550 mg/dl and serum HCO3- is 7.3 meq/L. What is the management of the patient in the first hour of admission as per the ISPAD protocol?
questions.solution:
The child with signs of shock has metabolic acidosis with hyperglycemia, likely has diabetic ketoacidosis (pH < 7.3, HCO3- < 18 mmol/ L, blood glucose>200 mg/ dl) requiring management on an emergency basis.
The management as per the ISPAD protocol guidelines is summarized below.
The management proceeds as per the dehydration status of the patient.
This child has signs of shock, and thus will require:
  1. A: Secure the airway and airway management ,B: Breathing with 100% oxygen and C: Bolus of 0.9% NS administration at 20 mL/ Kg (600 mL in this patient)
  2. Fluid management should continue by IV therapy with potassium supplementation as adequate based on ABG values and ECG monitoring
  3. Start insulin infusion 1 hour after initiation of IV fluid treatment. The dose of insulin is Dose: 0.05–0.1 U/kg/h of regular (soluble) insulin.


Reference: Glaser N, Fritsch M, Priyambada L, Rewers A, Cherubini V, Estrada S, Wolfsdorf JI, Codner E. ISPAD clinical practice consensus guidelines 2022: Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state. Pediatr Diabetes. 2022 Nov;23(7):835-856. doi: 10.1111/pedi.13406. PMID: 36250645.

questions.text: A 3-week old child with mild rhinorrhea and nasal congestion previously had apnea after cough paroxysms. What drug should be given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The neonate experiencing mild rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, cough paroxysms and an episode of apnea most likely has pertussis infection.
Bordetella pertussis is the causative organism.  
The management of this case will be as follows:
  • Hospitalization: Pertussis < 3 months old child is an indication for hospitalization.
  • Isolation: Droplet precautions for 21 days (untreated) or 5 days (after treatment)
  • Supportive care: Fluid, nutrition, avoiding triggers for cough paroxysms
  • Antimicrobials:
    • The macrolide antibiotics - erythromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin are the preferred antimicrobial therapies for the treatment of pertussis
    • Azithromycin is the drug of choice in all age-groups, for treatment or postexposure prophylaxis.
    • For neonates it is given as 10 mg/kg per day in a single dose for 5 days.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 1493.

questions.text: A 4-year old child has a lymphocyte count of 65000 cells/ mm3. Which of the following is common?
questions.solution:
The 4-year old child with a lymphocyte count > 50,000/ mm3 has lymphocytosis.
  • An increase in circulating lymphocytes (lymphocytosis) can be seen following infections such as infectious mononucleosis and pertussis, or in lymphoproliferative disorders such as acute and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)/lymphoblastic lymphoma (LBL) is the most common childhood malignancy.
