Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 596.

questions.text: A child presents with a history of late wound healing and repeated infection. Dryness and rash is noted around the mouth and nose. Which mineral deficiency is likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
These constellations of findings given represent zinc deficiency in the child and are managed by oral supplementation of zinc.
Severe zinc deficiency is characterized by dermatitis with the following features:
  • Typically erythematous, scaly, vesiculobullous, or pustular lesions
  • Site: Perioral and perianal areas or on extensor surfaces of the limbs



Acrodermatitis enteropathica refers to an autosomal recessive condition where absorption of zinc from the GI tract is impaired. It requires a higher dose of oral zinc supplementation.

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31th Edition, Page. No- 263.

questions.text: A child came with the following finding. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible?
questions.solution:
The given image shows bowing of the legs or genu varum, which occurs due to Rickets that results from the deficiency of vitamin D. Deficiency of vitamin D results in poor calcium/phosphate absorption in gut and that in turn results in poor mineralization(deposition of Calcium/Phosphate) of bone, leading to rickets.  


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2531.

questions.text: A child presents with petechial rash, hepatosplenomegaly and jaundice. Periventricular calcifications are seen and the screening test for hearing is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child with petechial rash, HSM, jaundice, periventricular calcifications (as shown in the NCCT below) and hearing loss has a constellation of findings which are most consistent with congenital CMV infections.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1488.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl’s mother had a history of cervical cancer and she was operated for the same. What advice will be given to the girl?
questions.solution:
An adolescent girl with a history of cervical cancer in her mother (first-degree relative) is being advised counseling for prevention and/ or early identification of the same.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is central to the development of cervical neoplasia and can be detected in virtually all cases of cervical cancer. 
  • Primary prevention of cervical cancer targets prevention of HPV infection by vaccination against HPV is the most suitable method to prevent the development of cervical cancer in the patient.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 3th Edition, Page. No- 630.

questions.text: A female presented to the gynecology OPD with a foul-smelling bloody discharge per vaginum mixed with mucus. She gives a history of multiple sexual partners. The patient is diagnosed with cervical cancer extending to the left parametrium with lateral wall involvement. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient with bloody vaginal discharge and a history of multiple sexual partners likely has persistent HPV infection, which is implicated in the etiopathogenesis of cervical cancer, which was diagnosed in this patient.
  • The management is based on the staging of the patient:
  1. Left parametrium involvement indicates that the stage of the patient is at least IIB (revised 2018 FIGO cervical cancer staging system)
  2. Since lateral wall i.e. pelvic wall invasion is seen, this indicates extension to the pelvic wall, which is most appropriately staged as stage IIIB.
  3. Stage III disease is considered locally-advanced disease, for which we administer primary chemoradiation.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 665.

questions.text: A young female presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of pain on standing and walking. She has a  history of multiple sexual partners. Visual inspection findings are shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classical history of the patient presenting with such severe pain and swelling that patients often find it difficult or impossible to walk, sit, or have sexual intercourse, with the typical vulvar lesion : Bartholin abscess.
Blockage of the Bartholin ducts is a common etiology of a vulvar mass.


Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 103.

questions.text: A young female has lower abdomen pain for one month. She reports mild intermenstrual bleeding and dysuria with scanty vaginal discharge which had subsided on its own within a week.  She has a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This female is most likely to suffer from pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The most common cause of PID is sexually transmitted diseases (STD), with gonococcal and chlamydial infections being the most common.
  • While chlamydial infection is often subacute and remains undiagnosed, Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection frequently presents as acute PID, as in this patient.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 68.

questions.text: A 15 year-old patient came to the OPD with her mother with a complaint of primary amenorrhea. On physical examination her height is 155 cm, the breasts are not developed and there is no pubic or axillary hair. On TVS, the uterus, FT and ovaries are not seen. Inguinal region swellings are noted. What is the most probable diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggesting that our patient is suffering from a disorder of sexual development (DSD).
Critical findings include :
  1. Normal height (rule out Turner)
  2. Amennorhea
  3. The absence of ovaries (female gonads) with the presence of bilateral inguinal region swellings, which likely indicate cryptorchid (undescended) testis.
  • The absence of Mullerian duct structures including fallopian tube and ovary indicate that anti-Mullerian hormone is functional in this patient.
  • However, the expectation of menses and amenorrhea in this female, indicate that the patient has female external genitalia and phenotype, likely due to defect in androgen synthesis or activity.
  • Another key point is the absence of the development of breast (Tanner Stage I) which was expected as per the age and female phenotype of the patient.
  • Thelarche is dependent on estrogen, rather than androgens.
This indicates that there isn’t enough androgen production for aromatization to take place, indicating that testosterone production is deficient in this patient.
Those having no significant testosterone production appear female at birth and present at puberty with primary amenorrhea and sexual infantilism, lacking both pubic hair development (due to the lack of testosterone) and breast development (due to the absence of aromatizable substrate); the serum LH concentration is elevated (hypergonadotropic) and testosterone levels are abnormally low (hypogonadism).
  • Complete androgen insensitivity (XY DSD) patients usually are well-feminized due to excess androgen levels which are converted to estrogen by the process of aromatization. Thus, while pubic/ axillary hair are scanty due to androgen insensitivity, estrogen ensures development of breasts in such patients. (option B)
Mullerian agenesis patients generally have well-developed gonads, since ovaries are derivatives of the genital ridge and not affected in this XX DSD. (option C)

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 375.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum in the upper 1/3rd of the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year old female with primary amenorrhea has cyclical abdominal pain every month. On physical examination she has a suprapubic bulge. P/R examination reveals swelling along the whole length of vagina. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The young female with primary amenorrhea experiences cyclic pain every month. The presence of a suprapubic bulge raises suspicion of cryptomenorrhea, which is confirmed by a per-rectal examination which reveals hematocolpos.

Causes of cryptomenorrhea include:
  1. Intact/ imperforate hymen: seen as bluish bulging membrane.
  2. Transverse vaginal septum: On examination, the vagina may appear shortened and the cervix may not be identifiable. Secondary sexual characteristics appear normal. The diagnosis can be confirmed with ultrasound or MRI. (option C)
  3. Vaginal agenesis: Vaginal introitus is not visible. On examination, the hymenal ring is normal, proximal to which only a vaginal dimple or small pouch is found. (option B)
  4. Agenesis of the lower vagina: A vaginal dimple may be noted on external inspection. Since these girls have normal cyclic pituitary-ovarian-endometrial function at menarche, the upper vagina will distend with blood products and secretions, which can be palpated as a mass on recto abdominal examination. Ultrasound and MRI may be used to help define the presence of a uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 418, 421.

questions.text: Which of the following cases in the OT will you manage hysteroscopically?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy can be performed for diagnostic or therapeutic indications.
Indications
  • Suspicion of the intracavitary lesion.
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • Abnormal endometrial thickening.
  • Intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome)
  • Postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Infertility.
  • Mullerian congenital anomaly.
  • Removal of foreign bodies.
 
  1. Asherman syndrome :The role of hysteroscopy is diagnostic and also therapeutic in such patients since adhesiolysis can be performed. 
  2. Submucous fibroids require resection by the hysteroscopic approach and, this approach is a first-line approach for heavy menstrual bleeding due to such fibroids.
  3. Laparoscopic sterilization is the main method for interval (ie, sterilization not performed postpartum) female permanent contraception. 
  4. Endocervical polyps, also referred to as cervical polyps are mucous polyps that arise from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal. They are simply treated by avulsion or by torsion, to the extent that no anesthetic agent is needed for this.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 146, 212.

questions.text: A 22-year old female brought by her mother-in- law to the gynecology OPD complaining of inability to conceive for the last six months. She has been cohabiting with her husband without using any contraception. Her BMI is 23 kg/m2. What will be the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Infertility is defined by the failure to achieve a successful pregnancy after 12 months or more of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse or due to an impairment of a person's capacity to reproduce either as an individual or with her/ his partner.
While the definition of infertility has historically included a time-interval of 12 months, investigation and treatment for primary infertility is initiated depending on the age of the patient.

Thus, the next line of management involves reassuring the patient that they should continue efforts to conceive for the next 6 months.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 428.

questions.text: A female undergoing treatment for infertility with IVF was given Inj. HMG, presents with a history of vomiting, nausea, and headache. The USG is shown below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A female receiving human menopausal gonadotropin (LH/ FSH) injection as part of her IVF treatment for infertility is experiencing symptoms of abdominal distension and discomfort including nausea and vomiting with Sonography revealing enlargement of ovaries with multiple cysts.
This is most likely due to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, which is the most serious complication of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) for assisted reproduction technologies (ART). 

* Extra Edge:
  • OHSS treatment is generally supportive. Paracentesis is typically performed transvaginally as an outpatient and can ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory disttess.
  • Re-accumulation of ascites may prompt additional paracenteses or rarely placement of a percutaneous "pigtail" catheter for continuous drainage.
  • Untreated hypovolemia can lead to renal, hepatic, or pulmonary end-organ failure. Thus, fluid balance must be maintained by replacement with an isotonic fluid such as normal saline.
  • Monitoring of electrolytes is critical. Because of hypercoagulability in these women, prophylaxis for thromboembolism is strongly considered with severe OHSS.
  • During exogenous ovulation, strategies to avoid OHSS induction include decreasing follicular stimulation (a lowered FSH dose), "'coasting" (withholding FSH administration for one or more days prior to the hCG trigger injection), prophylactic treatment with volume expanders, and substitution of hCG for FSH during the final days of ovarian stimulation.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 457.

questions.text: A female patient, currently pregnant, visits the hospital for a routine ANC visit. She has a history of a term twin delivery 3 years back. What is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
The obstetric score of a pregnant woman who previously delivered twins at term would be G2P1.
The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows:
  • Gravidity (G): Total number of pregnancies, irrespective of the outcome, including the present one. Thus G2 implies two pregnancies in this patient, the first one 3 years back, and the present pregnancy for which the patient is seeking ANC care. Since, this is the number of pregnancies rather than the number of children, the twin pregnancy is counted the same as a singleton pregnancy. Thus, the gravida is taken to be 2, and not 3. (option C, option D)
  • Parity (P): Denotes the total number of previous pregnancies, irrespective of the outcome that have crossed the period of viability, which is 28 weeks at most centers in India. In the Western countries, this is to be taken as 20 weeks of gestation due to better neonatal and maternal care. Central institutes such as the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at AIIMS, New Delhi take this cutoff to be 24 weeks. Since, this is the number of pregnancies rather than the number of children, the twin pregnancy is counted as a single parity. The current pregnancy is not included in the score. Thus, the parity for this patient is taken to be 1. (option B)
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 177.

questions.text: A multipara ANC patient at 36+6 weeks PoG has a fetus with transverse lie, not in labor. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and the liquor is adequate. What is the next line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
• There is no mechanism of labor in transverse lie and an average size baby fails to pass through an average size pelvis.
  • When the diagnosis of a singleton fetus in transverse lie is made before the onset of labor and in the absence of contraindications to a vaginal birth, we perform external version (ECV) to cephalic presentation at 37+0 to 37+6 weeks of gestation, as amniotic fluid volume is maximal and uterine tone and fetal weight are less than later in gestation, which likely improves success rates.
  • Abundant amniotic fluid (as in this patient) improves the success of ECV.
  • Patient counseling includes a discussion regarding small but real risks for placental abruption, preterm labor, and fetal compromise. Bradycardia is common during or following ECV, but emergent cesarean rates are ≤0.5 percent. Uterine rupture, fetomaternal hemorrhage, alloimmunization, amnionic fluid embolism, and maternal or fetal deaths are rare. Overall, compared with expectant management, perinatal morbidity and mortality rates are not greater with ECV.
  • Even alter successful ECV, several reports suggest that the cesarean delivery rate does not completely revert to the baseline or vertex presentations. Specially, dystocia, malpresentation, and non-reassuring fetal heart patterns may be more common in these fetuses who have undergone successful ECV.

Fig: External cephalic version. With an attempted forward roll, clockwise pressure is exerted against the fetal poles.


Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 528.

questions.text: A 36 weeks pregnant lady presents with difficulty breathing and back pain. Her BP is 124/85. On examination, the symphysial fundal height is 41 cm, and the abdomen is tense, non-tender. Fetal parts were difficult to palpate. There is no bleeding p/v. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is a 36 week pregnant female experiencing dyspnea and back pain. There is a significant discordance (> 3 weeks) between her PoG and SFH.
In the normotensive patient, with a non-tender abdomen with difficulty in palpation of fetal parts and absence of any bleeding PV, this is likely to be due to polyhydramnios.
  • Abnormally increased amnionic fluid volume complicates 1 to 2 percent of singleton pregnancies.
  • Hydramnios may be categorized as mild is the AFI is 25 to 29.9 cm; moderate, is 30 to 34.9 cm; and severe, is ≥35 cm.
  • Using a single deepest pocket of amnionic fluid, as is done in multifetal gestations, mild hydramnios is defined as 8 to 9.9 cm, moderate as 10 to 11.9 cm, and severe hydramnios as ≥12 cm.
  • Mild hydramnios accounts for approximately two thirds of cases and is frequently idiopathic and benign.
By comparison, severe hydramnios is far more likely to have an underlying etiology and to have consequences or the pregnancy.


Fig: Amnionic fluid index (AFI) according to gestational age–specific and threshold values.


Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 257, 258.

questions.text: A female presents with 6 weeks amenorrhea with complaints of spotting and pain. An adnexal mass is felt and the USG shows uterine cavity with no fetus. The hCG levels are 2800 IU/L. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This female with secondary amenorrhea for 6 weeks has spotting with pain and presence of an adnexal mass, which on ultrasound reveals a uterine cavity without a living fetus and elevated hCG levels are findings that point towards a diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy.
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea in a woman of childbearing age is pregnancy.
  • Hemodynamic instability or sudden onset of severe symptoms usually suggests a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • This patient is likely to have an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.
Medical management can be preferred in patients with the following:
  1. Hemodynamic stability
  2. Sac size
    1. In the absence of cardiac activity: <4 cm
    2. In the presence of cardiac activity: <3.5 cm
  3. hCG levels < 3000 IU/ L
  4. No other contraindications to methotrexate therapy
  • In this patient, it is not indicated specifically if any of the above criteria are not met, thus the preferred management would be a Methotrexate single-dose protocol where the calculated dose is administered as a single intramuscular injection is the treatment of choice.
  • Multi-dose protocol where the dose of methotrexate is given for 4 days on alternate days with leucovorin rescue in the intervening days is currently not used due to higher risk of toxicity. The single-dose protocol is less expensive, requires less intensive monitoring, and does not require leucovorin rescue. (option A)
  • Oral methotrexate is not used due to low success rate. (option B)
  • Definitive indications for surgical management include hemodynamically unstable patients, as in ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingostomy or salpingectomy may be performed. (option D)

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 221,225.

questions.text: A pregnant female has complaints of light-headedness and dizziness on lying down. This is relieved when the patient lies in the left lateral position. What is the cause of the light-headedness?
questions.solution:
This scenario represents postural hypotension which is well-described as supine hypotension.
When the patient lies supine during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus has a compressive effect on the inferior vena cava and resultant decrease in venous return leading to described clinical features of syncope.

Reference: DC DUTTA's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th Edition, Page. No- 61.

questions.text: A patient is in labor and the following image shows the trace of her partogram. What is the next management action in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given graph represents the modified WHO partograph of a patient in labor which is a graphical representation of the progress of labor in which cervical dilatation and descent of fetal head is plotted against the time, as well as maternal and fetal vital parameters.
Summary of the partograph findings, as seen in this patient are summarized below:
  1. This a multiparous female (G2) with the fetus showing signs of fetal distress(bradycardia and meconium-stained liquor).
  2. 3+ molding i.e., fixed overlapping of bones is present
  3. Slow progression of labor (overall the rate of dilation has been 6 cm in 8 hours which is less than 1 cm/ hr.
  4. The contractions are seen to be adequate.
Thus, in a pregnant female with adequate contractions in the presence of molding and slow progress of labor with signs of fetal distress, the  diagnosis is likely to be cephalopelvic disproportion.
Due to the presence of fetal distress, the patient should be managed by an immediate cesarean section.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 548.

questions.text: A pregnant female of 8 weeks POG came to the PHC with pallor. Her Hb is found to be Hb = 9 gm/dl. Which of  the following suggestions will you give to the mother?
questions.solution:
The scenario presents a female at 8 weeks gestation (first trimester) who has moderate anemia, defined as Hb ranging between 7 and 9.9.
As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat guidelines, this female requires treatment of anemia, and thus, will be treated as per the management protocol.
  • At all levels of care, the first level of treatment consists of double the prophylactic dose, that is, two tablets daily to be taken orally.
  • Thus, for this patient, this treatment should be initiated at the PHC visit itself at 8 weeks of gestation.
  • The female is followed up after 2 months and referred to FRU/ DH if no improvement after the first level of treatment.
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 1048.

questions.text: A patient underwent hysteroscopic removal of a fibroid. A fluid deficit of 2000 mL is reported. What is the most common immediate complication?
questions.solution:
In the context of hysteroscopic procedures, the term fluid deficit refers to the difference between the volume of distension fluid introduced into the uterine cavity and the volume of fluid that is removed or accounted for during the procedure.
A large fluid deficit (given here 2000ml)  indicates that a significant amount of the distension fluid has been absorbed into the patient's bloodstream.
This may lead to fluid overload resulting in pulmonary edema.

Depending upon the type of fluid used and the health status of the patient, when the fluid deficit reaches 500 mL, the surgical team should pause and assess patient status.
Criteria for termination of the procedure (and evaluating the patient for hyponatremia) are:
  • Electrolyte-deficient media (hypoosmolar): 1000 mL
  • Electrolyte-rich media (iso osmolar): 2500 mL for young patients with no comorbidities. May need to be individualized as per patient risk factors.
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 1054.

questions.text: A 35-year old obese female patient suffering from acne is not improving in spite of multiple cycles of isotretinoin and antibiotics. What is the next best in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A post-adolescent female patient with obesity has acne (papulopustular acne as seen in the image shown) not responding to multiple cycles of oral isotretinoin therapy.
Thus, the next step in this patient would be to rule out an underlying disorder such as polycystic ovarian syndrome which may lead to hyperandrogenism.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 393.

questions.text: A 50-year old woman develops features as shown below after application of hair dye. Which component of the hair dye is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The female after application of hair dye develops intense acute edema over the entire face, prominent in the periorbital region, likely, representing a hypersensitivity reaction to a component of the hair dye (contact dermatitis) 
A substance called p-phenylenediamine which is an azo dye intermediate, most commonly used in permanent hair dyes as a black dye is the likely agent responsible for the patient’s dermatitis.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 128.15, 89.73, 128.60.

questions.text: A child present with the following condition. The patient at the risk of malignancy in the future?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a child with an extensive black, heterogeneous, hairy palpable lesion on the left side of the face involving both the upper and lower eyelids.
The findings are suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus, specifically, a giant melanocytic nevus.
Especially in large congenital nevi, there is a risk for transformation to malignant melanoma.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 75.10, 143.7.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of multiple sexual partners presented with a single well defined perineal painless ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The sexually active female with a history of multiple sexual partners is at risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection.
The development of a painless ulcer (Hunterian chancre) and non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests primary syphilis.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 29.10, 29.15.

questions.text: A female patient, who is the wife of a truck driver with multiple sexual partners presents with vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, cervical erosions are noted. Which colored kit will be prescribed to the patient?
questions.solution:
• The female patient has likely contracted a sexually transmitted infection from her partner who has multiple sexual partners.
  • Syndromic management for her STI would be followed 
  • In the given scenario - she has vaginal discharge along with presence of cervical erosions - hence, she should be considered a case of CERVICITIS. (not vaginitis)
Hence, the female must be treated for cervicitis based on the algorithm:
  • She should thus be treated with the Grey kit.
  • This kit contains a single tablet of 1 gram azithromycin for chlamydia and a single tablet of 400 mg cefixime for gonorrhea.
  • As a rule, partner treatment is also advised in patients of cervicitis.


Reference: Gupta V, Sharma VK. Syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections: A critical appraisal and the road ahead. Natl Med J India 2019;32:147-152

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with swelling on the hard palate as shown. Which of the following is the most common condition causing this?
questions.solution:
The HIV positive patient with multiple, firm-appearing violaceous plaques on the hard palate is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, a multifocal epithelial tumor attributed to HPV-8 infection.
  • KS is considered an AIDS-defining illness.
  • The intraoral site most commonly affected is the palate followed by the gingiva.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 520, 522.

questions.text: A 50-year old patient having psychotic symptoms was started on a drug A after he had no improvement with haloperidol and thioridazine. This new drug A causes increased salivation, hyperlipidemia, and sedation. Which drug was he shifted to?
questions.solution:
The elderly schizophrenic patient has had a poor response to a trial of two drugs - haloperidol and thioridazine, which are both first-generation antipsychotics now on a new drugs experiences the mentioned symptoms. New Drug is likely Clozapine.

Indications of clozapine:
  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia, as in this patient
  • Schizophrenia associated with suicidal tendency
Adverse effects:
  • Agranulocytosis: This is the major side effect, which is why, it is reserved for refractory schizophrenia (dose-dependent side effect)
  • Metabolic side effects: Weight gain (highest weight gain among all antipsychotics), hyperglycemia, Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Seizures (dose-independent side effect)
  • Drooling and hypersalivation
  • Myocarditis
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3554, 3556.

questions.text: A 32-year old female presents with complaints of repeated episodes of around 30 minutes characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation and a fear of impending heart attack. The patient has been having these episodes 4-5 times in one month, for the last 6 months, and the investigations didn’t reveal any specific findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A middle aged female with episodes of hyperventilation and palpitations with a fear of impending doom lasting for about 30 minutes multiple times every month over the last 6 months represents recurrent attacks, establishing a diagnosis of panic disorder.
 
  • Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by chronic, multiple worries, anxiety and increased tension. This patient experiences recurrent, unexpected panic attacks. (option B)
  • Depression is characterized by sadness and anhedonia as the core features, with the diagnostic features popularly abbreviated as SIGECAPS. (option C)
  • Social anxiety disorder or social phobia involves anxiety restricted to social or performance situations with a fear of scrutiny and embarrassment. (option D)
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page. No- 394,396.

questions.text: A 32 year old male patient presents to psychiatry OPD with a history of recurrent premature ejaculation leading to interpersonal conflict. Which of the following is the non pharmacological treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
Pharmacologic therapy when combined with behavioral treatment appears to be more effective in treating premature ejaculation:
  1. SSRIs including paroxetine are the first-line treatment.
  2. The squeeze technique is a behavioral method used on the penis to prevent premature ejaculation. Here, the penis is stimulated until just before orgasm after which it is gently squeezed. It is particularly useful when psychogenic and/ or relationship factors are present such as the interpersonal conflict in this case.
  • Sensate focus therapy is a couple-oriented sex therapy that involves the exchange of sensual touch between partners to alleviate anxiety and negativity associated with sex and to build better sexual intimacy and communication. It is useful for the management of psychogenic erectile dysfunction. (option A)
  • Although cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for some patients with sexual dysfunction. It is not a specific technique for managing PE.(option C)
  • Exposure and response prevention therapy is a strategy effective in the management of OCD.  (option D)
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page. No- 577, 579.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with confusion and ataxia. He was unable to move his eye outwards.  On examination, there is 6th nerve palsy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A chronic alcoholic presents with the classic triad of:
  • Confusion
  • Ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
This is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2525, 3561.

questions.text:
Q. Palsy of which of the following nerves is an indication for the following?

1. Median
2. Ulnar
3. Radial
4. Volksman’s ischemic contracture
questions.solution:
The image shown above is that of a cock-up splint (Now known as Wrist hand Orthosis) 
The cock-up splint is used to manage radial nerve palsy.

  • Radial nerve palsy manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop).
  • Numbness occurs on the dorso-radial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 and a half digits.
Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page. No- 332.

questions.text:
Q2. A young boy presented with long standing knee pain without any definite history of injury. Which of the following is true based on the given image?

1. Superior pole patella fracture - cylindrical cast for 6 weeks
2. Patellar avulsion fracture - tension band wiring
3. Bipartite patella - obtain X-Ray of the other knee
4. Patellar avulsion fracture - interfragmentary screw fixation
questions.solution:
The young boy experiencing atraumatic knee pain with a frontal and a skyline view radiograph of the knee joint showing a smooth discontinuity with well-corticated borders is suggestive of an unfused accessory ossification center (Bipartite patella : two-part patella).

  • It usually is asymptomatic and is noted incidentally, however pain, when present, can be caused by overuse (such as in a cyclist or climber).
  • A fracture line running obliquely across the superolateral corner of the patella should not be confused with the smooth, regular line of a (normal) bipartite patella.
  • Checking the opposite knee is often the next step in the evaluation of such patients as bipartite patella is often bilateral.
  • Thus, this can be differentiated from superior pole patella fractures or avulsion fractures, which will have ragged margins. 
Reference: Pan T, Hennrikus W. Symptomatic Bipartite Patella in Adults Treated With Open Excision: Outcomes and Management. Cureus. 2022 Jul 9;14(7):e26705. doi: 10.7759/cureus.26705. PMID: 35959180; PMCID: PMC9359909.

questions.text:
Q3. An X-Ray film of a 22 year old female is provided. What is the probable diagnosis?

1. Giant cell tumor
2. Aneurysmal bone cyst
3. Fibrous dysplasia
4. Non ossifying fibroma
questions.solution:
The radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion at the distal ulna involving the entire epiphysis giving a soapy bubble appearance.
The age (20 - 40 years), site (wrist) and location (epiphyses) are consistent with a distal ulnar Giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page. No- 237.

questions.text:
Q4. A 20-year old male presented with shortening of left limb with multiple swellings in the limb and multiple skin lesions with irregular marking. X-Ray of the pelvis is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?

 
1. Fibrous dysplasia
2. Non-ossifying fibroma
3. Osteochondroma
4. Giant cell tumor
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Fibrous dysplasia

The young male with shortening of the left limb, multiple swellings and skin lesions is seen to have bending of the femur known as Shepherd's crook deformity on the radiograph of the pelvis. It is classically seen in fibrous dysplasia.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page. No- 249.

questions.text:
Q5. A 40-year old male presented with a history of long standing back pain, persistent early morning stiffness and redness of the eyes. On examination, chest expansion during inhalation is 3 cm. What is the most probable diagnosis?

1. DISH syndrome
2. Ankylosing spondylitis
3. Prolapsed IVD
4. TB spine
questions.solution:
The middle aged male with backache, morning stiffness and red eyes, likely representing an episode of iritis has limitation in chest expansion (<5 cm) with radiograph of the lumbar spine showing the classical ‘Bamboo spine' appearance.
This points to a diagnosis of Ankylosing spondylitis, also called Marie Strumpell disease.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page. No- 290.

questions.text:
Q1. Patient is kept in the following position when:

1. Patient is unresponsive, not breathing, no pulse
2. Patient is unresponsive, with pulse and breathing present
3. Patient is unresponsive, not breathing but pulse is present
4. Patient is unresponsive, breathing but pulse is absent
questions.solution:
This position is called the recovery or the semi-prone position which is used for patients who are unconscious but still breathing.
The recovery position is a useful position when airway is the primary concern, and will not address the circulatory compromise. 

  • The patient who is unable to breath is experiencing respiratory arrest : Rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to support the patient's breathing.
  • It is not physiologically plausible for a breathing patient to have absence of a pulse, as the absence of a pulse implies a lack of circulation, and breathing cannot be present without circulation.
Reference; Douma MJ, Handley AJ, MacKenzie E, Raitt J, Orkin A, Berry D, Bendall J, O'Dochartaigh D, Picard C, Carlson JN, Djärv T, Zideman DA, Singletary EM. The recovery position for maintenance of adequate ventilation and the prevention of cardiac arrest: A systematic review. Resusc Plus. 2022 Apr 29;10:100236. doi: 10.1016/j.resplu.2022.100236. PMID: 35515010; PMCID: PMC9065878.

questions.text:
Q2. Which maneuver is being performed?

1. Jaw thrust
2. Head tilt, chin lift
3. In-line spine stabilization
4. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation
questions.solution:
The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift.

  • It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.
  • Before performing this maneuver, it is essential to rule out cervical spine injury.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 2157.

questions.text:
Q3. This given device is used for all of the following except

1. Pulmonary toilet
2. Prolonged mechanical ventilation
3. Acute upper airway obstruction
4. Assessment of upper airway
questions.solution:
The given image shows a cuffed Tracheostomy tube.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Following are the functions of tracheostomy tube:
  • Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction - thus useful in upper airway obstruction. (option C)
  • Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance. It allows positive pressure ventilation.
  • Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  • Allows administration of anesthesia.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page. No - 1392.

questions.text:
Q4. Identify the procedure shown below:

1. Intraosseous fluid therapy
2. Intraosseous pain relief
3. Bone marrow aspiration
4. Intraosseous drainage of abscess
questions.solution:
The procedure being performed in the above image shows a needle inserted at the antero-medial aspect of the upper, proximal tibia  positioned at a 90 degree angle to the injection site.
This represents the intraosseous route access used for delivery of drugs and fluids, when an intravenous access cannot be secured.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page. No - 49.

choices.text: Apical segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient had a fever with a history of cough for the last 12 days. The CXR findings of the patient are as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient of fever with cough is noted to have an increased radiolucency in the right lung field in the given chest radiograph.
Obscuration of the right heart border is noted on the chest radiograph, suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1254.

questions.text: A 25-year old male presented with long standing right flank pain. His urine examination revealed sterile pyuria. What is the diagnosis based on the image findings as shown?
questions.solution:
The 25-year male with flank pain and sterile pyuria has a radiograph showing diffuse, homogenous alveolar calcification with a ground-glass appearance in the right flank region where the kidney is located pointing towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney.
  • Infection with atypical organisms, such as Chlamydia, Ureaplasma urealyticum, or tuberculosis are common causes of sterile pyuria, with genitourinary tuberculosis being an important consideration in the Indian setting.
  • Dystrophic calcification may result in a non functioning calcified kidney called 'putty kidney' or 'cement kidney.' 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 27th Edition, Page No 1045, 1046.

questions.text:
A 50-year old patient presented with a history of fall one week back with headache and dizziness. The patient is also a chronic alcoholic with the last episode of alcohol consumption 2 weeks ago. NCCT findings are as shown below. What is the diagnosis?

1. Subdural hematoma
2. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
3. Extradural hematoma
4. Intracerebral hemorrhage
questions.solution:
The elderly, alcoholic patient with a history of trivial trauma underwent NCCT due to symptoms of headache and dizziness. The following findings are seen on NCCT:
  • Hyperdense bleed: Representing an acute bleed with a small hypodense region likely representing ongoing chronic hemorrhage
  • Location: Left-frontotemporal region
  • Crosses the frontotemporal suture
The history and findings are consistent with a presentation of a subdural hemorrhage.

Note that, even though the shape of the bleed is somewhat lenticular rather than the classical crescent shape described for a SDH, the fact that it crosses the sutures is inconsistent with a diagnosis of EDH, which has a more dramatic presentation, since it is an arterial bleed.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3348.

choices.text: Small bowel mucosa is the most radio resistant in the abdomen.
Normal cells and cancer cells are equally susceptible to radiation
Radiation exposure is inversely proportional to square of distance from source of radiation.
Radiotherapy does not affect small vessels and capillaries.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding radiation in the abdomen?
questions.solution:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source in brachytherapy. This is described as the Inverse square law.
  • Radiotherapy works by targeting rapidly dividing cancer cells with ionizing radiation, which can damage the DNA of these cells and lead to cell death.
  • The gastrointestinal mucosa involves rapidly dividing cells, they are thus highly radiosensitive. 
  • Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells. This is the principle due to which radiotherapy is selectively able to target neoplastic tissue. 
  • Microvasculature involving the small vessels and capillaries is more susceptible as compared to larger blood vessels. 
Reference: Colledge J, Wilczek M, Chieng R, et al. Inverse square law. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 12 Dec 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-12424

questions.text: A 2-month old presents with swelling over his head since birth. The following X-Ray was taken. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A unilateral fluid collection bounded by suture lines of the skull with evidence of peripheral calcification is seen.
This is most likely a Cephalhematoma:
  • Cephalohematoma is a collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone (subperiosteal) of the skull, usually unilateral and over a parietal bone.
  • It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12-24 h.
  • The swelling is limited by the suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 452.
